text.value: No, upscale Abe Fisher isn’t a deli. But the flavors of the Jewish Diaspora are the primary source of inspiration at this creative Ashkenazi cousin to Zahav, where chef Yehuda Sichel’s masterful modern takes range from schmaltzy rugelach to Hungarian duck with kishke and steamed pretzel buns, cacio e pepe kugel, gefilte fish reimagined as whole stuffed bass and sublime chicken liver mousse over housemade rye. The giant Montreal smoked short rib feast, though, is a deli lover’s dream — and one of the greatest odes to smoked meat indulgence that Philly has to offer. Three-bell review: Abe Fisher.

As hidden gems go, Al Amana is up there with the best, not simply because of its obscure location inside a market behind the Al Aqsua mosque in Kensington, where it’s been for nearly 25 years. But also for the vivid flavors that the Palestinian Dabbour family has brought to the grill since they arrived in Philly nearly four decades ago from Syria, where they lived after their city, Safad, was partitioned into Northern Israel.

The food is homey and soulful, from the fluffy, herbal falafel to a baked halal lamb platter permeated with cinnamon and bay that’s an incredible deal at $9.50. My favorite item is the chicken shawarma that turns on a vertical spit as a Friday special, its layered thigh and breast meat deeply marinated in cumin, turmeric, and tangy lemon, then stacked into a perfect cone for even roasting that crackles at the edges. Bonus: the market has fantastic prices on big jugs of Nablus olive oil. Extra-bonus: the grill at the back of Liberty Choice Food Market (1939 N. Front St.) nearby is a kindred spirit, also with outstanding falafel, shish taouk and totally craveable housemade pita chips to go.

Northeast Philly is home to a pocket of immigrants from the state of Kerala, which has a distinctive cuisine that features flaky Malabar parathas and beef (due to its large Christian population). Head for the beef stewed Ulathiyathu-style in a spicy coconut gravy; but also the thick kingfish steaks braised in a sauce darkened with the deeply earthy sourness of black tamarind, a dish best eaten with kappa, boiled yucca mashed with coconut milk and aromatic curry leaves. For the ultimate Philly-Indian fusion, try the masala dosa stuffed with Kerala-spiced Philly cheesesteak and a side goat curry.

Ateethi also recently opened a Center City branch, a tiny Sansom Street nook with a considerably more limited menu (no cheesesteak dosa), with convenient all-in-one curry bowls and some North Indian favorites. The South Indian flavors, though, were most memorable, including a tender stewed chicken Chettinadu with vividly roasty spice, and a gobi Manchurian that was crispy, spicy, and sour.

This handsome newcomer to the all-day cafe game on Head House Square makes an array of fresh croissants, too. But the brioche spiral steals the show. Its coiled rolls of sweetness rise over its paper cuff like a tilting pastry turban encrusted with sugar nuggets. Tug at the top knot, and its center unfurls in a long moist ribbon of cinnamon-scented dough that’s gooey with caramel near the bottom. For a savory option, the veggie cutlet-and-egg breakfast sandwich is fast becoming a new obsession.

You’ll find tortillas in many colors at South Philly’s most complete Mexican restaurant (with fabulous margaritas and suave service), where the Sandoval family's birthright of heirloom corn is the real focus, and anything made with blue corn masa from their home in San Mateo Ozolco is worthwhile, shaped into oval tlacoyos, puffy chalupas, sopecitos, and vivid blue huarache. But look for the daily special featuring seafood, like fried oyster tacos with huitlacoche and chayote slaw over soft masa taco rounds turned green with fresh cilantro.
Three-bell review: Blue Corn.

Colorful masa specialties are the prime draw to one of the city’s best Mexican restaurants. But just as often, I crave Blue Corn's shrimp cocktail: a glass chalice of big, tender shrimp submerged in zesty tomato cocktail sauce fanned with avocados and raw onions (a splash of Jarritos orange soda is another secret). With a healthy extra splash of La Bruja, a spiced vinegar infused with peppers and herbs, eating this cocktail is the next best thing to a trip to Acapulco.
Two-bell review: Blue Corn.

It’s always sunny Margarita Season at one of the few restaurants in Mexican South Philly that has a bar. And it turns out some of the city’s most effortless variations on the classic — spiked with chile heat, tangy with hibiscus or tamarind, or smoky with mezcal — to make a feast of its colorful huaraches and tlacoyos even more festive.

This industrial riverward stretch of the lower Northeast used to be nicknamed Crab Alley, thanks to the abundance of corner tappies serving shell-cracking feasts. Most have disappeared, but colorful Bonk’s Bar, which dates to the 1950s, was thankfully rescued by the craft beer-forward team behind the Grey Lodge Tavern. Your choice of hot local blue crabs, dungeness, or snow crab clusters come beneath an upturned salad bowl (a.k.a. The Port Richmond cloche) in a variety of seasonings. A dusting of Old Bay spice is always my first instinct, but these being Philly crabs, the correct answer is to bury them in garlic butter.

Fried fish and buttery grits are a North Philly morning tradition, and it’s a worthy draw on the menu of Desiree and Robert Pollard’s fast-growing brunch empire. Their fourth Breakfast Boutique opened in Mount Airy this year (just as the Ogontz Avenue original closed), with the same quaint black-and-white decor as its Chestnut Hill branch, a Luther Vandross-soulful vibe, and fish worthy of the old Groben’s Seafood it replaced. The cornmeal-crusted whiting fillets were perfectly fried. But don’t sleep on those salmon cakes, either, whose crisp exteriors held big chunks of fresh fish bound in a moist mayo dressing that perked even more with a dip in the side vinaigrette.

We’ve had a run of good Cobb makeovers. But Marcie Turney has truly updated this retro salad beauty with her remastered Cobb. The chicken is roasted in sesame oil; shaved watermelon radishes and pepitas lend festive crunch; and smoky Nueske's bacon crumbles with creamy Buttermilk Blue for an indulgent bow to salad glory with a satisfying splash of Thai basil Green Goddess dressing.

Chef Chris Anton is Transylvanian, but his menu roams across the wide dumpling landscape of the former Soviet empire, with tortellini-shaped Siberian meat pelmeni gratineed Moscow-style and handmade vareniki plumped with sweet farmer’s cheese.

“Dandan Plus” is the best way to describe the colorful and supercharged “Ignite Noodles” at this modern counter service space in University City, where a young Chengdu native and Drexel grad delivers a lip-numbing taste of home for University City’s unofficial Chinatown West. This casual and affordable space with an open kitchen and whimsical panda murals also serves whole fish platters buried beneath a red blanket of dry peppers, dumplings glistening in sweet-and-spicy dark chile oil, and a hearty beef soup that’s also sour from house-fermented mustard greens.
Two-bell review: Chengdu Famous Food

Camden’s Queen of Soul Food, Corinne Bradley-Powers, has been keeping Haddon Avenue festive for three decades with a birthday-pink dining room and a reliable post-church Sunday rush. It could be the Cajun-spiced turkey wings, picnic-perfect black-eyed peas or sweet potato pie. But for me, it’s a traditional fried chicken that’s still the region’s best.

This is no fancy-brined breast or double-battered buttermilk pretender with eclectic spicing. Corinne’s is a reminder of the magic that happens when old-fashioned simplicity meets a master hand. And her fried chicken is minimalist perfection, simply rubbed with salt and pepper then shaken in a seasoned flour that creates a tawny cracker of heat-bubbled golden crust, revealing juicy meat inside.
“You don’t need all that ‘dipping this’ and ‘dipping that,’” she said. “All you need is some good, fresh chicken; make sure the grease is hot enough, and then fry it.”
To hear her describe it, it sounds simple. But there’s also three decades of soul-food success glowing in that bird, along with “a lot of love.”

Beth Amadio’s recently closed Main Line shrine to cutlets has found a sleek new city home beside Fitler Square, with retro Phila-Italian dishes (like the Milan salad) and her famous cutlet “Stack” in tow. So naturally her brunch hit is a Franken-stack, too — this time waffles sandwiching breaded chicken, sausage-stuffed long hots, and two sunny-side-up eggs sloshed in maple syrup. It’s essentially an Italianized version of chicken and waffles: spicy and sweet, crunchy, pillowy, and oozy rich, proving the cutlet can be my favorite food group any time of day.
Two-bell review: Cotoletta Fitler Square.

The cacio e pepe here is one of the city’s best, but it’s the zesty and indulgent “Chicken Riggies” — rigatoni with smoked chicken in a spicy blush sauce kicked-up with cherry peppers — that conveys the swagger of this lively Queen Village restau-bar and chef David Gilberg’s proud upstate New York roots.
Three-bell review: Cry Baby Pasta.

Italians Danilo D’Eugenio and Monica Fenocchio have the technology to fabricate their toothy fresh pasta in-house and the native palates to make it taste right. It’s nonetheless still a pleasant shock to order a fast-food version of tonnarelli in a peppery froth of creamy cacio e pepe sauce that tastes this good for under $15.

It doesn't get more humble than the community tables at the back of this market in West Philly, but no Indian kitchen in town delivers quite the punch of uncompromised spice as this counter-service kitchen featuring vibrant Punjabi flavors, from kadhi yogurt stew with pakora fritters to radish-stuffed paratha flatbreads and other northern Indian classics prepared simply with a home-cooked touch by the Singh family, which also makes my favorite tandoor-roasted chicken tikka.
Two-bell review: Dana Mandi.

The open fireplace hearth is the secret at intimate and clubby Alpen Rose, where “big meat” chops of dry-aged prime beef sizzle over glowing coals of oak and fruit woods, then get carved tableside for extra drama beneath the crystal chandeliers and barrel-shaped wood ceiling. I always opt for anything still attached to a bone for maximum savor, like the rib eye, bone-in strip, or gigantic Tomahawk that makes a carnivore’s showpiece worth sharing. But there’s also a throwback indulgence to the puff pastry-wrapped tenderloin of beef Wellington that’s hard to resist. It speaks to the retro aura of this clubhouse dining room, with its speakeasy door, tufted leather booths, and pocket bar that customizes cocktails from a card catalog dedicated to regulars’ favorite drinks. I’ve never included a steakhouse in my Top 25 before because the genre is saddled with cookie-cutter chains. But unique Alpen Rose is now the exception, because it’s Philly’s best independent luxury steak destination since Barclay Prime.
Three-bell review: Alpen Rose.

The standard playlist won’t do for the VIPs at this boutique steakhouse, where bespoke cocktails are created for regulars then saved as numbered recipes in its card catalogue. The No. 26, made for my friend Dave, is one I’d like to repeat as my own: the muscle of E.H. Taylor rye tamed with Luxardo maraschino liqueur and Dolin white vermouth, then dusted with grated coffee beans that lend each sip a roasty dark bass.

The original Amma’s in Voorhees first caught my attention as a top Indian favorite just last year. But Amma’s has ridden the South Indian flavor wave to Center City, and its newest branch, in an industrial rustic space on Chestnut Street, has drawn perpetual lines since the day it opened — for good reason.

"Amma" means mother, and those from Tamil Nadu will find the authentic flavors of home at this BYOB, where halal meats and fresh-ground spices result in thrillingly vivid flavors, from the all-natural Chicken 65 (none of that artificial pink) to a wickedly sour-and-spicy gobi Manchurian, yellow dal laced with whole red chiles and tangy gongura leaves, fluffy idli cakes, tart lemon rice, crispy onion rava dosas, and deeply-steeped curry stews rich with coconut milk and waves of complex spice. The crispy medu vada flecked with curry leaves and mustard seeds are the ultimate savory donuts. Finish your meal with a rich cup of Madras coffee, poured into a milky froth between two brass cups. The only thing holding Amma’s back from a three-bell rating is the service, which can be chaotic and overwhelmed. It nonetheless remains one of the most essential new restaurants in Philly right now.
Two-bell review: Amma’s.

Few developments have excited me recently as much the region’s awakening to the fragrant, distinctive spice of regional Indian cooking — particularly the crisp dosa crepes, coconut-scented stews, fiery biryani rice pots, and sour tamarind curries of South India. Until recently, though, that required a drive to Chester County or South Jersey, where the original Amma’s in Voorhees first caught my attention as a new favorite last year.

The South Indian wave has now arrived in Center City, and Amma’s new branch in an industrial rustic space on Chestnut Street has drawn perpetual lines since the day it opened — for good reason. "Amma" means mother, and those from Tamil Nadu will find the authentic flavors of home at this BYOB, where halal meats and fresh-ground spices result in thrillingly vivid flavors, from the all-natural Chicken 65 (none of that artificial pink) to a wickedly sour-and-spicy gobi Manchurian, yellow dal laced with whole red chiles and tangy gongura leaves, fluffy idli cakes, tart lemon rice, crispy onion rava dosas, and deeply steeped curry stews rich with coconut milk and waves of complex spice.

The crispy medu vada flecked with curry leaves and mustard seeds are the ultimate savory doughnuts. Finish your meal with a rich cup of Madras coffee, poured into a milky froth between two brass cups. The only thing holding Amma’s back from a three-bell rating is the service, which can be chaotic and overwhelmed. It nonetheless remains one of the most essential new restaurants in Philly right now.

There are so many reasons that charming Andiario in downtown West Chester is one of the best — if not the best — restaurants in the Pennsylvania suburbs. The commitment to seasonality and relationships with local farmers, the well-curated wine list divided between local and Euro choices, and the live fire hearth that perfumes the room and lends rustic depth to all the meats are just a few. A recent veal breast — smoked, then braised, then reheated over the fire before it was doused in meat juices and fava beans — still haunts me.

But the ever-changing pastas are absolutely the best reason to visit. Chef Anthony Andiario has mastered such perfect textures with his noodles that they enhance everything they touch. The hand-twisted snap of double-barreled strozzapreti cradles house-cured guanciale in zesty Amatriciana sauce. A creamy artichoke puree clings to twiny strands of pici that made sweet summer cherry tomatoes pop. And those perfectly folded tortelloni dumplings? Stuffed with milky sweet ricotta then topped with a wild harvest of golden chanterelles, they’re the silken pillows of my earthy dreams.
Three-bell review: Andiario.

Danny DiGiampietro’s pizzas exude a personality much like his own: bold, brash, and infinitely ambitious, with a deeply crusty savor and commitment to no-shortcut scratch cooking that’s more about passion for flavor than quick-buck common sense. Mozzarella? He makes his own. He roasts his own peppers. He makes the meatballs. The sesame-dusted rolls for those fantastic hoagies and steaks? Yeah, he bakes those, too. His pizza dough takes two days to ferment and develop the big holes that lend it the crunchy chew and extra substance to stand up to the toppings. Just not too many!

Go for two or three max to get the full effect on the sauce-topped Upside Down Jawn square pie, or the round spice bomb of the Diavlo, whose zesty arrabiata sauce is amped with even more fresh sausage and enough roasted long hots to give it a proper South Ninth Street swagger.

The crusty, sesame-speckled house-baked rolls are key for all the sandwiches at this hot new pizzeria in the Italian Market. So is the well-cooked, high-quality rib eye. But turn that roll into garlic bread for the “Tony Head,” and you have a simple but full-flavored twist on the cheesesteak that suddenly seems obvious, but also essential.

Yet another hot new pizzeria to raise the hoagie standard by baking its own rolls, Angelo’s makes bold sandwiches that are as much a draw as its pies. The most over-the-top among them is the Drunk Cutlet, at once a sloppy monstrosity and marvel of dairy excess — fresh mozz, creamy ricotta, and a pink wave of blush sauce — that overflows a hoagie boat of chicken cutlets that tastes pretty darn good sober, too.

By now, you expect the lines for lamb tacos. Because after this food cart-turned-taqueria earned well-deserved national notice, a James Beard Foundation finalist nod, and a showcase on Netflix’s Chef’s Table, most everyone now knows that South Philly Barbacoa is one of America’s ultimate destinations for, well, barbacoa.
“The best,” said TV host Andrew Zimmern, who happened to be at the taqueria on South Ninth Street recently interviewing chef Cristina Martinez. “She makes the fluffiest tortillas on the planet."

Zimmern was referring the velvety, pliant rounds Martinez pressed before roasting them on the plancha. They’re made fresh Pennsylvania corn grown from heritage Mexican strains that the restaurant nixtamalizes overnight and grinds into masa dough. The corn flavor is so fresh and vivid, it amplifies the power of the Capulhuac-style slow-cooked lamb that Martinez and her husband, Benjamin Miller, sell by the steamy kilo to weekend crowds that begin showing up at 5 a.m. Along with a bowl of chickpea-lamb consommé steeped from the drippings, and perhaps (no, most definitely) another taco filled with spicy pancita offal sausage, this is without a doubt one of the most profoundly satisfying meals in Philadelphia.

But now there’s another reason to visit. The deliberately limited menu has expanded to include quesadillas, which use the same extraordinary masa but are notable because they showcase fleeting seasonal ingredients – like squash blossoms or fresh huitlacoche – with the rare bonus of Oaxaca cheese the restaurant makes itself. The freshness of that mozzarella-like cheese, which I’ve not seen made anywhere else, adds a heightened sweetness and more luxurious texture as it melts, accenting the quesadilla’s griddle-roasted textures and fillings. So, whether or not you made it for the brief summer window of fresh huitlacoche season, you can be certain this line is worth the wait.
Three-bell review: South Philly Barbacoa.

There are two things you can be sure to eat at Bibou. One is an exceptional riff on foie gras, crisply seared alongside grilled apricots and cassis at my summer visit. The other is a seasonal hot soufflé, rising like the July beauty that perfumed our table with blueberries as goat’s-milk crème anglaise was poured into its quivering center. The rest of the eight-course, $115 tasting menu at this intimate BYOB in South Philly changes weekly. And that’s what I crave most from Bibou: the spontaneous artistry of one of Philly’s most talented chefs. Pierre Calmels, the former Le Bec-Fin star from Lyon, channels French gastronomy with a rare ease that always feels current.

The opening canapes alone are always a whimsical treat, from spoonfuls of melon bavarois dabbed with tomatillo jam and spiced pumpkin seeds to warm chorizo chips with juniper cream. Meaty lobster mushrooms call out to the real lobster mousse inside a silken pasta cannelloni. Don’t miss the game birds in the colder months when Calmels gets his hands on a grouse or pheasant. And when truffles are in season, Bibou is the place to let them fly, shaved generously across your Wagyu steak or stuffed quail by the white-gloved hand of one of its gracious longtime servers. It’s all part of the experience of an evening at posh Bibou, where the ability to make classic French elegance taste fresh and new on a weekly basis is the surest bet of all.
Read previous coverage: Bibou.

A clear tomato consommé adds a contemporary lightness to soupe au pistou that blooms with vivid color when the broth is poured over summer garnishes into the bowl.

This innovative South Kensington BYOB is everything you expect from one of our most progressive kitchens, a destination for hyper-seasonal cooking singed by the live-fire smoke of its Bertha hearth, whose campfire aroma pervades the room. The four-course tasting option, which delivers extra “banchan” bonus bites, is a smart way to go. That allows the widest slice of its repertoire, which leans toward edgy dishes like tartare of local veal (or bison) with charred kohlrabi ringed by caraway cream, or melt-away choux dumplings with anise-hyssop and intense seafood ragù, or a snowpile of shaved ice flavored with stone fruit for dessert.

When you dig into the details of Cadence’s signature two-part Alina duck feast — a juicy breast blast-roasted in stages over the coals then served with an agrodolce of capered green blueberries, plus a confit leg grilled to finish over smoked eggplant puree — it’s not surprising Food & Wine recently named this 38-seater the best new restaurant in America. The splash of national fame allowed the three former Fork chefs who co-own it to hire a dishwasher to spell them from their regular pot-washing duties.

I hope it also frees them to keep making their stellar take on roast pork, a porchetta that comes with a clever broccoli-and-pepper wink to Philly style. Its juicy center is infused with fennel and herbs wrapped in a cracker band of skin that bubble-puffs like a crunchy chicharron. With creamy white beans, wood-roasted peppers and broccoli on the side tossed in spicy ’nduja vinaigrette, a spoonful of rich pork, and duck jus fortified with hearth-burnt onions is all that’s needed to bring it home.
Three-bell review: Cadence.

It’s at its best with four-course tastings that deliver extra “banchan” bonus bites — and a $3 surcharge to supplement the staff’s group healthcare plan.

Cadence is your best bet for edgy dishes like tartare of local veal (or bison) with charred kohlrabi ringed by caraway cream, or tiny meltaway choux dumplings with anise-hyssop and intense seafood ragù, or a snow pile of shaved ice flavored with stone fruit for dessert. And when you dig into the details of Cadence’s signature two-part Alina duck feast — a juicy breast roasted with an agrodolce of capered green blueberries; then a confit leg over smoked eggplant puree — it’s not surprising Food & Wine recently named this 38-seater the best new restaurant in America. The splash of national attention finally allowed the three former Fork chefs who co-own it to splurge on a dishwasher to spell them from their regular pot-washing duties.

I hope it also frees them to keep making their stellar take on roast pork, a porchetta that comes with a clever broccoli-and-pepper wink to Philly style. Cadence cooks through half a local pig at a time, so the primal parts rotate. But the essentials remain the same: a juicy center infused with fennel and herbs wrapped in a cracker band of skin that bubble-puffs like a crunchy chicharron. With creamy white beans, wood-roasted peppers and broccoli on the side tossed in spicy ’nduja vinaigrette, a spoonful of rich pork and duck jus fortified with burnt onions is all that’s needed to bring it home.

The burger is often a griddle-seared bellwether of the times, a stage for the latest toppings, a vessel for the technologies that shape our foodways, even a barometer of our real estate economy. But Charlie’s Burgers, the Delco throwback to elemental slider comfort that dates to 1935, has long been a reluctant holdout. That history was genuinely in danger, though, when Charlie’s was forced to abandon its old location this year and move to a generic Folsom strip mall on East MacDade Boulevard. Suffice it to say, it left its old burger shack charm behind.

But those timeless flavors have definitely made the leap. Just ask the Charlie’s faithful. A mail carrier named Doug sitting at the table beside me even said a little prayer of thanks over his tray of two cheeseburgers — his monthly order since he began coming during high school the 1970s. As for the latest edition of those greasy little patties, all stacked up in humble doubles loose and crumbly inside the snug softness of their griddle-crisped buns? “Oh, my …,” I thought, as the savory warmth washed over and I tried to eat them slowly, wishing I’d ordered more.

The Bunny, Charlie’s, and Peg special combos have transcended the move and not lost one ounce of their old-school griddle powers. Postman Doug enthusiastically devoured his lunch — and so did I, buoyed by the added innovation of French fries (a Charlie’s first) and sips of a chocolate shake still in its frosty metal cup. My quiet prayers to the Burger Gods were answered, too. Charlie’s has survived!

It’s best to come early to the dim sum frenzy at China Gourmet, when you can still get a seat and the varieties of dumpling treasures inside the steamy metal carts rolling through this massive pink dining room in Northeast Philly are at their most diverse. The translucent white skins of hand-pleated har gao dumplings snug inside their metal trays around pristine stuffings of sweet minced shrimp. Silky rice rolls topped with tender snips of steamed short ribs. Deep-fried shrimp balls wrapped in crispy noodles that trail golden ribbons like a dumpling comet. The delicate snap of crinkly bean curd skin rolled around meaty stuffings moistened with gravy. And then there are the "Snow Mountain buns" (xue shan bao), warm white rounds filled with anise-tinged barbecued char siu pork whose domed crusts are laced with the crunch of baked sweet cream.

Bowls mounded with tiny clams glossed with funky dark fermented black-bean sauce beckon, as do the long hot peppers stuffed with pork, and steamy lotus leaf bundles stuffed with sticky rice and sausage. And then there’s an entirely separate kitchen menu of masterful Cantonese cooking to consider from chef-owner Ming Fung, whose live seafood tank and jet-fired woks produce an epic variety of lobster, crab and shrimp dishes that make this dim sum palace not simply one of the city’s largest restaurants, catering to the growing Chinese community in Northeast Philly, but also one of its best.
Three-bell review: China Gourmet.

It’s best to come early to the dim sum frenzy at China Gourmet, when you can still get a seat and the varieties of dumpling treasures inside the steamy metal carts rolling through this massive pink dining room in Northeast Philly are at their most diverse. The translucent white skins of hand-pleated har gao dumplings snug inside their metal trays around pristine stuffings of sweet minced shrimp. Silky rice rolls topped with tender snips of steamed short ribs. Deep-fried shrimp balls wrapped in crispy noodles that trail golden ribbons like a dumpling comet. The delicate snap of crinkly bean curd skin rolled around meaty stuffings moistened with gravy. And then there are the "Snow Mountain buns" (xue shan bao), warm white rounds filled with anise-tinged barbecued char siu pork whose domed crusts are laced with the crunch of baked sweet cream.

Bowls mounded with tiny clams glossed with funky dark fermented black-bean sauce beckon, as do the long hot peppers stuffed with pork, and steamy lotus leaf bundles stuffed with sticky rice and sausage. And then there’s an entirely separate kitchen menu of masterful Cantonese cooking to consider from chef-owner Ming Fung, whose live seafood tank and jet-fired woks produce an epic variety of lobster, crab, and shrimp dishes that make this dim sum palace not simply one of the city’s largest restaurants, catering to the growing Chinese community in Northeast Philly, but also one of its best.
Read previous coverage: China Gourmet.

Daniel Gutter added a round pie option when he moved his Pizza Gutt pop-up (at W/N W/N Coffee Bar) to a new permanent corner in Fishtown. But the reason fans begin lining up at 5 p.m. is the hefty Detroit-style squares that come edged with an awesomely crunchy lace of caramelized cheese and topped with racing stripes of sauce. Go white pie for the full cheesy-bread effect. My favorite combo includes black olives, sausage, and spinach.

Chad and Hanna Williams’ sophisticated remake of Friday Saturday Sunday is by all measures one of Philly’s most polished destinations for contemporary fine dining. The bi-level corner rowhouse is a picture of intimate charm, with a cozy bar on the ground floor where people graze on icy raw bar plateaus and sip inventive cocktails like the smoked eggplant spritz — so good! The upstairs dining room exudes special-occasion romance. And if you want a low-drama steak, roast chicken, or whole duck for two, FSS delivers some of the city’s best.

But Chad is one of Philly’s most ascendant culinary talents right now because, three years in, his menu has captured a distinctively daring groove. His hyper-diverse kitchen team (African American, Dominican, Japanese, and “some guys from Indiana,” he jokes) channels their cultures and personal memories as a jumping-off point and then cooks with a cheffy zest for adventurous off-cuts and intense flavors paired with an elegant polish few can match.

Tender sweetbreads are fried into dainty katsu tea sandwiches moistened with bone marrow tartar and served on a marble pedestal. Mexican menudo lends a back beat to Rancho Gordo beans beneath a meaty arm of crisp octopus. Philly-style spaghetti and crabs finds another level of tidal punch with the unexpected twang of smoked herring. Black crumbles of house-made morcilla blood sausage and crunchy pork cracklins elevate frilly edged creste di gallo pasta tubes with rich sofrito sauce to something truly memorable.

Sadly, there were no takers for the whole pig face our charming server did his best to sell. But our appetite for adventure had been more than sated. We were ready for the comfort of dessert, and pastry chef Tish Smith’s gorgeous upside-down cake with apricots and coriander ice cream delivered.
Read previous coverage: Friday Saturday Sunday.

The War on Christmas is another wry-but-beautiful seasonal entry in bartender Paul MacDonald’s “Fibonacci” cocktail series, whose ingredients are proportioned in descending halves based on a 13th century math sequence. This winter inspiration, mixed from aquavit, Cardamaro, Madeira, Ramazzotti, and Creole shrubb, evokes the caraway spice, citrus, and dried fruit of the season with a finishing hit of bitters.

The smouldering-hot BYOB called Hearthside in Collingswood has made the convincing leap over the past few years from “best restaurant in South Jersey” to being one of the most exciting restaurants in the entire region, period. Any one of Dominic Piperno’s inventive pastas, or the tea-braised pork belly lacquered in a beet-red char siu glaze, or the dry-aged porterhouse cooked over coals, could compete on any Center City corner.

If there is a single reason, though, that I’d show the fortitude to land a reservation months in advance and pay the bridge toll to get to Hearthside, it would be the majestic prawns. Sizzling in a cast-iron pan after a blast inside the wood-fired hearth, these massive head-on beauties trail a fragrant plume of garlic-scented chile butter steam across the candlelit dining room to my table. Jealous heads turn because they’re mine — all mine! First comes the delicate snap of those sweet Gulf crustaceans, the closest I’ve encountered to Louisiana-style BBQ shrimp since leaving New Orleans. Yhen comes a messy deep dive into the molten pool of zestily spiced, buttery seafood juices left behind. Sop up all that shrimp glory with grilled rounds of Hearthside’s excellent house bread and know it was worth the commute.
Three-bell review: Hearthside.

You expect good loaves from a place named after its hearth. But clever creations in the bread basket, like the soft focaccia tanged with a shade of rye (paired with house-cultured Parmesan butter) reveal the fully formed identity of a kitchen in the groove. There are other beautiful renditions of more traditional focaccia made daily at Zeppoli (618 W. Collings Ave., Collingswood, three bells), Melograno (2012 Sansom St., three bells), Fiore (757 S. Front St., three bells) and Vetri (1312 Spruce St., four bells) where it’s made from house-milled grain.
Three-bell review: Hearthside.

The smouldering-hot BYOB called Hearthside in Collingswood has made the convincing leap over the last few years from “best restaurant in South Jersey” to being one of the most exciting restaurants in the entire region, period. Any one of Dominic Piperno’s inventive pastas (say, the basil agnolotti stuffed with smoked eggplant) or the tea-braised pork belly lacquered in a beet-red char siu glaze, or the delicate crudos, dry-aged porterhouse cooked directly over coals, or even the bread basket with rye focaccia and Parmesan-whipped cultured butter — all could compete on any Center City corner.

If there is a single reason, though, that I’d show the fortitude to land a reservation months in advance and pay the bridge toll to get to Hearthside, it would be the majestic prawns. Sizzling in a cast-iron pan after a short blast inside the wood-fired hearth, these massive head-on beauties trail a fragrant plume of garlic-scented chile butter steam across the amber candlelit dining room to my table. Jealous heads turn from neighboring tables, because they’re mine — all mine! First comes the delicate snap of those sweet Gulf crustaceans, the closest I’ve encountered to Louisiana-style BBQ shrimp since leaving New Orleans. Then comes a messy deep dive into the molten pool of zestily spiced, buttery seafood juices left behind. Sop up all that shrimp glory with grilled rounds of Hearthside’s excellent bread and know it was worth the commute.
Read previous coverage: Hearthside.

Our current wave of bread craft and higher grain awareness lifted off in 2013 at Fork’s innovative next-door sibling under then-chef Eli Kulp and opening baker Alex Bois, who turned out swirl-topped anadama loaves, ultimate potato bread comfort, stylish squid ink bialys, and the pioneering Keystone loaf made from freshly milled Pennsylvania grains from Castle Valley Mill. The daily bread selection is still inspiring, served with fresh jam and butter infused with Deer Creek malt syrup, and fresh creations are expected soon, from new baker Alexander Roman.
Three-bell review: High Street on Market.

In an era that’s all about local sustainability, chef Scott Schroeder $30 “dinner burger” at Hungry Pigeon, made from eight ounces of naturally raised local veal, is an extraordinary creation. Aside from the caraway-scented pain de mie roll baked fresh by partner Pat O’Malley, this occasional special (depending on availability) is truly an homage to Chester County cheesemaker Birchrun Hills Farm. The farm’s grass-fed veal is raised in a humane, free-range manner that bears no resemblance to the horror of factory-farmed veal.

The meat is both delicate and flavorful as a rose pink-colored patty, but comes gratineed in the full-flavored funk of Birchrun’s washed-rind Red Cat cheese, piled high with sauteed wild mushrooms, garlic aioli, and shaved ham from Country Time Farm that lends a subtle pork accent. But that’s not all. When it arrives with crunchy nuggets of potatoes roasted in beef fat, a carafe of hot veal jus steeped from the same animal’s bones is poured over the whole thing. It’s a messy, extravagant and thought-provoking burger feast — one of the few I don’t mind eating with a knife and fork.

Believe it or not, I frequently come to Hungry Pigeon for a healthy breakfast: a tasty chia pudding with seasonal fruit and homemade granola I just can’t quit, or, on hungrier mornings, a hipster breakfast bowl of brown rice congee sparked with sprouted lentils, fermented kimchi, and a spicy runny egg. It’s as hearty as it is beautiful. But going the virtuous route requires no small display of willpower considering the other options here, like the stunningly good egg-and-cheese breakfast sandwich on a homemade English muffin available with fresh sausage or legendary Lancaster bacon. Or the buttermilk biscuits with creamy gravy, or those banana bread sticky buns. But I’ll fess-up to one consistent weakness: Whenever I come for my sensible breakfast at this breezy all-day cafe in Queen Village, I’ll almost always scoop up a bag of warm croissants to go. For the “family.”

I mean, who can resist the masterful baking from partner Pat O’Malley? The former Balthazar pastry whiz makes remarkable croissants, rich with cultured Euro butter and a sweet hint of Pennsylvania honey, that beckon with crackly golden crusts that are rarely more than 20 minutes out of the oven. Grab any variety you can once the pans hit the counter early each morning — ribboned with Valrhona chocolate; rich with almond cream; oozing with bechamel, ham, and cheese; or just those beauteous plain croissants puffed with airy centers that are laced with intricate pastry scrolls. They don’t last long, because they’re simply Philly’s best.

(While Hungry Pigeon makes my ultimate croissant, it’s hardly the only local bakery rolling out artisan viennoiserie greatness. Also look for any morning pastry from Machine Shop Boulangerie, Fiore, Walnut Street Cafe, Cake Life, Le Petit Mitron, Malvern Buttery, Vernick Coffee Bar, or Ici Macarons and Cafe.)
Three-bell review: Hungry Pigeon

I could come up with a different craving for every meal at Hungry Pigeon, the breezy Queen Village corner on Fabric Row that has redefined the freewheeling possibilities of the all-day cafe trend thanks to the two chef-owner-buddies who run it like a house party. Count on updated comfort foods for lunch and dinner from Scott Schroeder (ex-South Philadelphia Tap Room, American Sardine Bar), from the special-order fried chicken and lasagne to first-of-season soft-shell crabs and Philly’s ultimate luxury “dinner burger,” an epic patty of Chester County veal with Red Cat cheese and country ham that gets drenched tableside with hot veal jus. It comes and goes off this menu, like so many other items depending on supply, seasonality, and Schroeder’s whims du jour.

What you can always rely on at Hungry Pigeon, though, is the masterful baking from partner Pat O’Malley, the former Balthazar pastry whiz whose crackly croissants, rich with cultured butter and a sweet hint of Pennsylvania honey, are usually less than 20 minutes out of the oven. Grab any variation you can once the pans hit the counter early each morning — ribboned with Valrhona chocolate; laced with almond cream; oozing with bechamel, ham and cheese; or just go for those beauteous plain croissants whose airy centers are laced with intricate pastry scrolls. They won’t last long, because they’re simply Philly’s best.

The same could be said though, for O’Malley’s pies. Their butter-rich crusts achieve a Jedi Grandma-level flakiness that wrap seasonal fruits and vividly steeped fillings, from sour summer cherries to fluffy banana custard to genuine Thanksgiving pumpkin richness with pumpkin seed whipped cream — in the fresh-baked glow of high pie Americana.
Read previous coverage: Hungry Pigeon.

The notion of a $125 tasting menu being “fun and accessible” sounds improbable until you take your seat at Laurel, Nicholas Elmi’s contemporary atelier on East Passyunk Avenue. There’s classic rock in the air, a team of somms pouring obscure wines, cocktails with crazy names like “Robot Space Bear,” and a caviar course inspired by French fries dunked in a milkshake. And you know what? When my spoon slid into the cut crystal bowl layered with briny bowfin roe, cold sweet beads of nitro-frozen cream and crispy potato crumbs, that is exactly what it tasted like — upgraded with the kind of playful luxury wink that Elmi routinely gets away with.

The former Top Chef champ and Le Bec-Fin alum is entering year six at Laurel with a new cookbook, a more modest ($85) menu option, and a cool gray interior makeover this fall. And he hasn’t lost a step as one of our most inventive talents in showcasing the seasons through a modern American gaze.

A perfect duck breast gains savory momentum with unexpected echoes: a house-fermented duck garum glossed over grilled cucumbers and a crispy cube of duck scrapple. Smoked cod, hidden beneath yellow squash, comes with crispy white puffs dusted with nori and vinegar powders that add yet another mysterious layer of depth to fish. They’re made from cod bladders, which take two days to prepare and two minutes to devour. Fun, accessible, cravable cod bladder chips?! Elmi’s gastro-idol status is certified.
Read previous coverage: Laurel.

The former Top Chef champ and Le Bec-Fin alum is entering year six at Laurel with a new cookbook, a more modest ($85) menu option, and a cool gray interior makeover this fall. And he hasn’t lost a step as one of our most inventive talents in showcasing the seasons through a modern American gaze. An opening shot of carbonated melon soda delivers the improbable effect of multiple flavors from one gulp, a sphere of green tomato-tomatillo dashi bursting with tartness (and bloomed basil seeds) after the melon’s sweetness fades. Pickled green strawberries spark surf clam ceviche. Moss green sorrel gelee brightens the Sweet Amalia oysters.

Popeyes has nothing on this Northern Liberties chicken specialist, which serves a boneless fried chicken sandwich that’s not just juicy and tender, but sealed inside a buttermilk-batter crust that clings to the meat until it shatters at the bite. The hefty original standard is already a beauty for $8.75 with spicy slaw on a bun that gets toasted with chicken-amping schmaltz. But Todd and Laura Lyons’ take on Nashville hot chicken is a double-fistful of next-level flavor, with the kind of lip-stinging swagger, crunch, and gushing-moist flesh that demands you chase it with a slice of pie.

This fun-loving Kensington gastropub has always been on the avant-hoagie-garde, its “veggie jawn” sparked by a brilliant “coppa” terrine of fermented carrots, the sweet smoke of Lebanon bologna tangling with kimchi aioli and pineapple jam for Da Dutchie. Leave it to Martha to hoagie-fy the waffle, too, mixing bits of charcuterie into the batter, then layering it with salad over long hot pepper pesto and maple syrup for the ultimate sweet-’n’-spicy brunch insanity.

For the last two years, I’ve added a bonus No. 26 to my Top 25 to acknowledge an unconventional place that quite doesn’t fit traditional restaurant categories. Last year it was the exclusively members-only Palizzi Social Club. This year’s pick is one of Philly’s most forward-thinking bars: Martha.

For a place that doesn’t cook much beyond an expansive pickle program, it’s amazing how many food conversations wind their way back to Jonny Medlinsky’s funky revamp of a onetime Kensington chop shop, from its inventive hoagie riffs to local cheeses, vegan options, and tomato pie. But Martha is first and foremost a bar, and that’s where it most stands apart: as a community crossroads for Kensington’s artisan revolution and especially as the region’s premier showcase for local spirits, wine, and beer, not to mention a somewhat off-theme but impressive collection of mezcals.

Medlinsky’s mission is primarily local, and Martha carries more than 100 spirits from 30 local producers for its inventive cocktails, with flights of regionally produced whiskey, and a series of amari from Rowhouse Spirits right next door. Martha was also the first to offer a sizable collection Pennsylvania and Jersey wines by the glass. Still skeptical about local wines? Take a glass of Va La’s La Prima Donna orange wine, Galen Glen’s grüner, or Vox Vineti’s rosé into Martha’s shady beer garden, toss a round of bocce ball, then thank me later.

For the last two years, I’ve added a bonus No. 26 to my Top 25 to acknowledge an unconventional place that doesn’t fit traditional restaurant categories. Last year it was the exclusively members-only Palizzi Social Club, which remains an all-time favorite for updated red gravy magic. This year’s pick is one of Philly’s most forward-thinking bars: Martha.

For a place that doesn’t cook much beyond an expansive pickle program, it’s amazing how many food conversations wind their way back to Jonny Medlinsky’s funky revamp of a onetime Kensington chop shop, from tomato pie to inventive hoagie riffs that dabble in Lancaster meats, kimchi and a fermented carrot “coppa” terrine for the surprising Vegan Jawn. Even the waffle gets a Martha hoagie makeover with charcuterie in the batter, long hot pesto and maple syrup for the ultimate sweet-’n-spicy brunch insanity. A revolutionary vegan “cheese” about to make its debut? I tasted it at Martha first.

But Martha is first and foremost a bar, and that’s where it most stands apart: as a community crossroads for Kensington’s artisan revolution and especially as the region’s premier showcase for local spirits, wine, and beer. Medlinsky carries more than 100 spirits from 30 local producers for its inventive cocktails, with flights of regionally produced whiskey, a series of amari from Rowhouse Spirits right next door and a big collection Pennsylvania and Jersey wines by the glass. Still skeptical about local wines? Take a glass of Va La’s  La Prima Donna orange wine into Martha’s shady beer garden, toss a round of bocce ball, and thank me later.

The sad demise of MeltKraft sent me into grilled cheese withdrawal, but I’ve recovered thanks to the range of appealing sandwich combos at this crafty Bourse vendor, which pairs the butter-toasted, crusty loaves of the Mighty Bread Co. with indulgent compositions from Stargazy’s Sam Jacobsen. I’m a fan of the simplest combo, Happy Together, that blends the sweet spice of hot honey with Amish cheddar on sourdough. Other restaurants like High Street on Market (308 Market St.), Talula’s Daily, and Alimentari have equally tapped my craving for haute grilled cheese.

Everyone covets a hoagie secret, that corner deli that locals know but never mention because they want it for themselves. Well, brothers Tommy and Mike Palestino made it 35 years before I stumbled into their South Philly corner and fell head-over-hoagie for their fiery Inferno, an imported-meat Italian laced with fat-marbled “gabagool” and the extra kick of  a long hot. Mi-Pals rises on the sliced-to-order standard, but also satisfying takes on other standards like fresh chicken cutlets. Just don’t ask where they get their perfect rolls: “That?” says Tommy, “I’d like to keep a secret.”

Parc’s roast chicken is the kind of perfect French brasserie bird that trails such an intoxicating aroma as it heads through the dining room that it taps you on the shoulder and says, “Order me.” To the credit of the city’s busiest restaurant, it seems to get even better each year, reaching a level of herbal moistness, parchment-crisp skin and rich amber jus that can only be completed with a crock of Parc’s silky mashed potatoes.
Three-bell review: Parc.

With a tawny crisp exterior and the chewy white heart of its well-developed and holy crumb, this masterful baguette anchors the O.G. of serious bread baskets in Philly, alongside crusty sourdough boules and hearty slices of cranberry-walnut. I have friends who refuse to come anymore to Parc for fear of eating only bread. But that bread basket embodies Parc’s French soul, and it’s one of the prime reasons this brasserie remains Philly’s busiest restaurant.
Three-bell review: Parc.

Juan Carlos Romero, who ran the original Los Taquitos de Puebla, has landed at another good taqueria in South Philly. But he’s at his best in the outdoor settings of the seasonal farmers markets at Head House Square (Sundays) and the Cherry Street Pier (Saturdays) when his turning trompa spit is stacked tall with a cone of al pastor meat glistening with guajillo marinade beneath a crown of roasting pineapple.

There’s serious pizza karma baking in this Fishtown spot left behind by the original Beddia. And the new occupants have fast become one of the best slice shops in town, with plank crisp pieces ringed by char-bubbled, well-developed crusts worthy of the legacy. Chef Marcello Montagnaro has a special touch for white pies, whose cream bases are infused with lemon or basil, dolloped with sweet fresh ricotta and garnished with seasonal toppings. It’s far more accessible than its predecessor, but still known to occasionally run out of dough.

I’d come for the agrodolce chicken, because chef Michael Vincent Ferreri’s talent with the roasted bird, which arrives shined with a honey-kissed sweet-and-sour sauce, is completely engrossing. Except when I looked up, Res Ipsa’s kitchen was in such a groove that I suddenly coveted everything else on its menu.

Ferreri’s pastas, served at dinner only, are as powerful a draw to this minimalist all-day cafe as anything. Gnocchi Sardi, dimpled from being rolled against a perforated colander, tumble with eggplant in spicy arrabiata. Hand-twisted trofie come with vivid green pesto Sicilianized by raw pistachios, orange and a medley of minty herbs.

Spaghetti alle vongole, however, is the dish I truly obsess over. The briny sweetness of delicate cockles tossed with a fistful of parsley over al dente pasta in a white wine sauce tinged with lemon, garlic, and sea is the ultimate example of simplicity mastered. And, sorry chicken, it demands my full attention.
Three-bell review: Res Ipsa.

The most beautiful, intricate salads in town come from chef Michael Vincent Ferreri’s kitchen. He spins in-the-moment whimsies like a flower-dappled cloud of foraged alliums and colorful blooms for spring, and a summer ode Butter Crunch lettuce whose leaves were layered around Caesar-flavored bread crumbs like a lettuce nesting doll.

The chicken was calling. It had been awhile since I’d visited Res Ipsa, and this minimalist all-day cafe had slipped off my Top 25 in 2018 in favor of some new arrivals. But recently, I found myself dreaming of its whole chicken in sweet-and-sour agrodolce. Was it Philly’s best bird?

Chef Michael Vincent Ferreri takes three days to prepare his plump Lancaster chickens, salt-curing them overnight, then roasting breast-side down for juiciness atop vegetables that shift throughout the year, lending subtly evolving seasonal accents. He then lets them cool and collect their essence overnight before blasting them to a crisp for dinner. Glossed to finish with a mahogany shine of juices tanged with vinegar and a kiss of honey, what emerges is roast chicken as a gravitational force: inescapable, essential, magnetically delicious.
Three-bell review: Res Ipsa.

The chicken was calling. It had been awhile since I’d visited Res Ipsa, and this minimalist all-day cafe had slipped off my Top 25 in 2018 in favor of some new arrivals. But suddenly, I was dreaming of its whole chicken in sweet-and-sour agrodolce. Was it Philly’s best bird?

Chef Michael Vincent Ferreri takes three days to prepare his plump Lancaster chickens, salt-curing them overnight, then roasting breast-side down for juiciness atop vegetables that shift throughout the year, lending subtly evolving seasonal accents. He then lets them cool and collect their essence overnight before blasting them to a crisp for dinner. Glossed to finish with a mahogany shine of juices tanged with vinegar and a kiss of honey, what emerges is roast chicken as a gravitational force: inescapable, essential, magnetically delicious.

Except when I looked up, Res Ipsa’s kitchen was in such a groove, I suddenly coveted everything else on its menu. Ferreri makes some of the most artful salads in town, from a flower-dappled cloud of foraged spring alliums to a summer Butter Crunch with leaves layered around Caesar-flavored bread crumbs like a lettuce nesting doll. The riffs on caponata, from classic eggplant to grilled spring artichoke, stamp Res Ipsa’s Sicilian pedigree.

Ferreri’s pastas, meanwhile, are as powerful a draw as anything. Gnocchi Sardi, dimpled from being rolled against a perforated colander, tumble with eggplant in spicy arrabiata. Hand-twisted trofie come with vivid green pesto Sicilianized by raw pistachios, orange, and a medley of minty herbs. Spaghetti alle vongole, though, is the dish I obsess over. The briny sweetness of delicate cockles tossed with parsley over al dente pasta in white wine sauce tinged with lemon, garlic, and sea, is the ultimate example of simplicity mastered. And it demands my full attention. Uh-huh. Those clams are calling now.
Read previous coverage: Res Ipsa.

The stacked-patty homage to the Big Mac has now become the preferred format for the upscale burger, as chefs finally acknowledge the virtues of a quick and consistent sear — harder to achieve with fat patties. Some of my city favorites have it down, from Royal Boucherie (52 S. 2nd St., three bells), where the hi-lo combo of American cheese and truffle mayo with a Machine Shop bun, bacon, and pork-fat fries goes down extra nice with $2 lunch martinis, to the other commendable contenders at Common Bar & Grill (3601 Market St.) and a.kitchen (135 S 18th St.).

My current double-patty idol, however, is the suburban savory bomb at Ardmore’s Ripplewood Whiskey & Craft (29 E Lancaster Ave.). Chef and co-owner Biff Gottehrer stacks two quarter-pounders from Exceptional Foods with extra fat content and dry-aged beefy oomph between melty layers of Gouda, house-pickled onions, a "special sauce" with smoked tomatoes, capers, and shallots over a pain au lait bun that's soft without being eggy. Most important, it’s got local personality: two thin pads of fried Lebanon bologna slipped between the patties that add a touch of smoky sweetness where, in other burgers, bacon plays the common role. It lends a catchy Dutch savor to a gusher so juicy (ordered medium-rare), that you'll need two hands to eat it, and most likely several napkins.

You can find uber-trendy drinks blended with everything from carrot to marmalade at Ardmore’s go-to cocktail haven. But my purist instincts leap at the perfect Whiskey Sour here. One of the region’s most impressive spirit collections (200 whiskies!) is put to good use with the choice of rye-high Eagle Rare bourbon to anchor the lemony tang and Angostura-traced frothy coupe of this beautiful classic.

As luxury sushi finally gains downstream momentum in Philadelphia, the restaurant-inside-a-restaurant that is Jesse Ito’s omakase haven at Royal Sushi remains the ultimate raw fish score. This serene 10-seat hideaway is tucked behind Royal Izakaya, the sake-fueled (three-bell) Queen Village gastropub marked only by a red lantern that serves an à la carte menu of Japanese tavern classics. And while the $130 omakase tasting is no small commitment for a modest meal that might require a post-tasting gyoza platter, if you obsess over sushi, the 18 pieces of seafood perfection Ito hands across the counter may well be the 18 best bites of your year.

Each morsel of rare fish — most imported from Japan, wild and meticulously prepared — delivers a radiating pleasure, the bundles of flavor and texture dissolving around warm nubs of perfect rice. A scallop was intricately scored into shag-like frills that multiplied its natural sweetness, focused by soy and drops of lime. Sea bream sashimi over agar jelly threads shimmered between Thai chile sauce and the earthy luxury of shaved summer truffles, which made an even more memorable fusion cameo later, grated into a mountain over warm balls of rice.

There was a nori cup brimming with briny sweet hairy crab, sword-tipped squid dusted with grated lime, rosy sea bass, and luscious otoro crowned with caviar. A ribbon of engawa, sliced from a fluke’s fin, delivered a taut snap of delicate richness. And then, in a puff of drama, Ito lifted a small glass dome that sent sweet cedar smoke rolling down the counter. When it cleared, deep orange slices of rainbow trout beckoned like treasure from a Japanese smokehouse. If you like it as much as I did, here’s a tip: Raise your hand like a regular to bypass the online scrum and reserve the next omakase from your seat.

There's something uniquely satisfying about an ashak dumpling, which highlights the green appeal of wilted scallions and spinach as a stuffing, then submerges them in a meaty orange puddle of lamb gravy streaked with rich yogurt and dusted mint.

The skewers are always the draw. When I close my eyes and think of Saté Kampar, it’s the intoxicating smell of its marinated chicken, goat, and pork threaded onto sticks sizzling over coconut coals that inevitably first launches me on the road to this evocative BYOB on East Passyunk Avenue — destination Malaysia. Served with two kinds of complexly rendered saté sauces — the Malay Kajang vivid with chile oil and house-roasted peanuts; and the fruitier Hainanese Melaka — a feast of saté skewers is always a given.

But I’ve also come to view Saté Kampar as much more, a thrilling portal to a seemingly endless world of Malaysian wonders, from nasi lemak banana leaf bundles of coconut rice, anchovies and spicy sambal, to silken beef rendang infused with cardamom followed by cups of “cham” (half coffee, half tea) poured to a froth at the kopitiam coffee bar. And every time I return, chef Angelina Branca conjures yet another transporting flavor from her childhood in Kuala Lumpur.

Her nasi kerabu fried chicken platter with sky-blue rice launched the butterfly pea flower craze that’s blossomed across the city. Branca’s bold recent mission to expose Americans to the pungent allure of durian fruit has also made a convert out of me — especially fermented into a spicy sambal dip for crudite. And I can think of no better way to ring in 2020 than the all-you-can feast of chili crabs and skewers she’s planning for New Year’s Eve. The complex crab sauce alone, a bewitching and messy brew of lemongrass, galangal, fermented shrimp, tamarind, and tomatoes, is the finger-licking flavor of crazy rich Southeast Asian good fortune.

Don’t sleep on Peter Serpico. I’m guilty of that myself, perhaps because South Street remains a drag to visit, despite the draw of the acclaimed chef’s collaboration with Stephen Starr. Or perhaps because the relentless stream of openings means a restaurant that debuted with novel mad scientist style in 2013 is no longer such a novelty. But after a convincing revisit in which Serpico and his young crew cooked their way back into my Top 25, I won’t overlook him again.

Among the most compelling plates were seafood dishes that touched both Serpico classics, like his poppy-dusted scallop crudo in buttermilk with green yuzu koshu, and the delight of newer creations. They’re rendered with modernist techniques that may now be more mainstream than they once were. But they’re never just tricks: they work in service of a superior culinary mind who sees food differently than anyone else.

A good example can be found in stunning ceviche showered with a hale of rice-cracker pearls that spark every bite of fish and kohlrabi bits soaked in citrusy clam juice with a chorus of crunch. Hot doughnuts are made sea-savory with nori powder for a dip in smoked fish cream. A gorgeous halibut, meanwhile, is crusted in a layer of savory carrot cake — spiced with Old Bay in a nod to Serpico’s Maryland crab cake roots — that caramelizes into a crust that also protects the delicate fish from ever touching hot metal. Fish and carrot cake? Only Serpico could make me crave that now.
Three-bell review: Serpico.

Don’t sleep on Peter Serpico. I’m guilty of that myself, perhaps because South Street remains a drag to visit, despite the draw of the acclaimed chef’s ambitious collaboration with Stephen Starr. Or perhaps because the relentless stream of openings means a restaurant that opened with novel mad scientist style in 2013 is no longer such a novelty. But after a convincing revisit in which Serpico and his young crew cooked their way back into my Top 25, I won’t overlook him again.

There are still crave-worthy originals that count as Serpico classics, from the poppy-dusted scallop crudo in buttermilk to the boneless fried duck legs shined with a hoisin and tucked into hot dog rolls. But the anticipated surprise of new dishes is what draws me back to the chef’s counter in this broodingly handsome space. The techniques that once defined him as a leading modernist in a town resistant to molecular gastronomy are now mainstream. But here they work in service of a superior culinary mind who simply sees food differently than anyone else.

Exhibit A: a stunning ceviche showered with a hale of rice-cracker pearls that spark every bite of fish and kohlrabi bits soaked in citrusy clam juice with a chorus of crunch. Hot doughnuts are made sea-savory with nori powder for a dip in smoked fish cream. Favas are minced into rice-sized bits to become their own green “risotto” beneath tender lamb loin and honey-glazed strips of layered lamb belly. And a gorgeous halibut is crusted in a layer of savory carrot cake — spiced with Old Bay in a nod to Serpico’s Maryland crab cake roots — that caramelizes into a crust that also protects the delicate fish from ever touching hot metal. Fish and carrot cake? Only Serpico could make me crave that now.

The dusky herb smell of wild za’atar roasting with onions and sesame over man’oushe flatbreads in the wood-fired hearth. The lemony tang of chicken shish taouk kebabs singed oh-so-close to the glowing coals. The earthy silk of lamb tartare — kibbeh nayyeh — pressed into a dimpled pink round topped with crunchy sumac-dusted onions and mint. These traditional Lebanese flavors are rendered so beautifully at Suraya, they evoke the Beirut childhoods of mega-developer Roland Kassis and his sister, Nathalie Richan, who named it after their grandmother.

Framed by the spectacular block-long space they’ve built in Fishtown, where Kassis has driven the Frankford Avenue resurgence, Suraya is also a gilt-ceilinged dream palace that set a new standard of ambition for this emerging neighborhood as Philly’s best new restaurant of 2018. With partners chef Nick Kennedy and Greg Root, they’ve created a compelling contemporary experience that works all day, from flaky morning kouign-amanns scented with cardamom sugar, to dukkah-dusted mezze lunches with fresh-baked pitas, and inspired dinners paired with Middle Eastern wines and arak cocktails that can be sipped in the vast al fresco oasis garden in back.

Kennedy’s menu hits a rare sweet spot between tradition and modern style, with worthy haute takes on baharat-spiced lamb neck and whole dorade in a spicy pepper-walnut harra sauce. But it’s ultimately the Lebanese classics rendered at their very best I want, like the intensely smoky baba ganoush that’s hand-chopped and whisked, then topped with Urfa pepper flakes and tart jewels of pomegranate seeds. For dessert I need the warm kanafeh of sweet shredded phyllo stuffed with oozy cheese. It comes with a cruet of rose blossom syrup, mini-pitas dusted with sesame and a promise: Suraya can transport you around the globe and back to Fishtown in a single bite.
Three-bell review: Suraya.

Few restaurants can match the all-purpose appeal of Talula’s Garden for a special occasion. If it’s beautiful weather, you’ll want to grab a peach sangria and sit outside in its magical, light-strung garden overlooking Washington Square. But it’s a delight to dine any time of year in the farmer-chic glow of its rambling dining rooms, where chef Charles Parker’s menu delivers local seasonal bounty on generous plates framed by regional American inspirations.

But if there is one trait that distinguishes Talula’s Garden, it is co-owner Aimee Olexy’s shrine to cheese. A calling to evangelize the beauty of artisan curds has followed Olexy throughout her career, from pioneering Django to Talula’s Table, her four-bell Kennett Square market cafe and tasting room, to her latest project on Rittenhouse Square, the Love. But Olexy’s obsession shines brightest on the more expansive stage of the Garden, where there are 40 local and international cheeses at any given time behind her counters (and neighboring all-day cafe, Talula’s Daily) that land on the multiple themed cheese slates, artfully trimmed with seasonal fruits, nut brittles, jams and honey.

And it’s often the best place to taste the latest cheese news firsthand. Curious about the most recent champs from American Cheese Society’s national competition? Olexy had a collection from this year’s winner’s circle within a matter of weeks — grassy orange Dorothy’s Comeback Cow, Caulkin’s Creamery’s brie-like noblette, and beer-washed Bamboozle from Goat Rodeo — oozing ripe and ready on a slate.
Three-bell review: Talula’s Garden.

The chef names continue to change, but after a dozen years, an evening feast at the big country table of this Kennett Square market and cafe remains one of the most magical BYOB dining experiences available. The consistent thread of excellence is owner Aimee Olexy, who orchestrates several 10-course menus with her chefs throughout the year that never repeat. At my most recent meal this summer, then-chef Dylan Sweeney served up a vivacious green tomato ceviche; house-smoked pastrami with horseradish-beet bavarois and pickled mustard seeds in a cabbage leaf wrap; a stunning snail dish with garlic panisse; meltingly rich salmon; an inventive duck duo with ramps and strawberries; Olexy’s legendary cheese course (Boursin made from Lancaster goat cheese!); and the barrage of irresistible breads baked by partner Claire Twesten.

By fall a new chef, Kyle Beebe, was turning out gorgeous tuna au poivre, romesco pork, and Dijon gnocchi with multicolored cauliflower. I’ll have to return for one of Beebe’s menus — and will wait until then before reaffirming the Table’s steady four-bell status. But there’s a reason these two tables (including a smaller new table in the front window nook) continue to book a year in advance. Olexy’s big-city collaborations with Stephen Starr (Talula’s Garden, The Love) have worthy mass appeal. But the intimate dinner parties at her own little Table in Chester County bear Olexy’s unmistakably personal stamp.

I first was smitten with Mike’s BBQ when I devoured Mike Strauss’ take on the smoked brisket cheesesteak, an essential pit boss twist on the classic Philly sandwich. But I’ve since returned enough to recognize this little storefront off the East Passyunk corridor has evolved into the closest thing Philly has to an all-purpose smokehouse champ. At my most recent visit, an ice cooler by the register was brimming with the irresistible hospitality of free Miller High Lifes — a perfect consolation to the inevitable long lines. But when it was my turn, I loaded-up a tray of smoked meats that are definition of crave-worthy, with a perfect combination of deep flavors, telltale pink smoke halos, and moist tenderness that can sometimes be elusive. The spare ribs, pulled pork, and cracker-skinned pork belly are fantastic. And there are other dishes, like the hearty chili brimming with smoked meats, bacon-wrapped burnt ends, cast-iron cornbread, and “Phillie Phattie” sausage stuffed with gouda mac-and-cheese that show Strauss’ bottomless creative wit. But there’s really only one thing I need at Mike’s: his cumin-scented peppery brisket, a thick slice of beef still so moist and quiveringly tender, that one bite makes the eyes roll skyward. It’s the essence of pure Philly BBQ pleasure, with or without its cheesesteak.

Before Res Ipsa’s shiny agrodolce darling caught my eye, Vernick’s whole bird was my hands-down chicken crush — and the cover model for my first Ultimate Dining guide. I may be distracted now by so many other Vernick delights, but it’s still the ideal emblem for a chef whose cuisine is far more involved and powerfully flavored than it appears. It's brined, steamed, reinjected with its juices, then roasted in the restaurant’s wood hearth until it is no longer just a chicken — it’s a crackly-skinned spirit bird.
Four-bell review: Vernick Food & Drink.

Six grains of sea salt. That’s the exact number of snowy white flakes the chefs must count out to garnish — and spark — the otherworldly flavors of the uni crudo at Vernick Food & Drink. That may sound oddly precise, but it speaks to the extraordinary details that go into chef Greg Vernick’s wide-ranging modern cuisine, which often looks simple, but is in fact intricately layered with subtle contrasts of texture, temperature, and focused flavors.

And that crudo, one Philly’s greatest dishes, is a prime example. A cool orange tongue of sweet urchin arrives hovering over a rippling cloud of whipped yogurt. But as the spoon plunges into the bowl, it finds the comforting warmth of custardy eggs at the bottom, soft scrambled with shrimp butter that deepens its tidal pull. Eaten together in one gulp, waves of flavor wash over: the foam of dairy richness, a lactic yogurt tang, the cool sweet urchin dissolving like chantilly cream into the deep sea savor of those warm eggs. And then a sudden crackle of tumbling salt on the finish harmonizes it all, commanding your spoon to return.

It’s that kind of compulsive deliciousness that powers so much of Vernick’s menu and makes the chef’s Walnut Street namesake a destination for so many elemental desires. Considering his consistent touch with seafood, though, it’s no wonder the recently opened Vernick Fish in the new Comcast Technology Center is one of the year’s most eagerly anticipated openings. It’s still too new for its formal review. But Vernick’s devoted fans, no doubt, are counting on it.
Four-bell review: Vernick Food & Drink.

Vedge is a rare place that bridges two worlds: the universe of vegans dedicated to plant-based eating and omnivores willing to set aside their blood-thirsty ways for an evening of “fancy radishes” and eggplant braciole because Vedge is one of the best restaurants in Philly, no matter the category. And over the last eight years, it’s checked all the boxes for destination status, from its remake of a historic townhouse manse, to its trendsetting natural wine list and cocktails, to the polished service and pioneering cuisine.

I crave a crock of rutabaga fondue — with a fresh soft pretzel for scooping — more than any real cheese (or Cheez) dip it evokes. And when I slice into the big wood-roasted carrot over pumpernickel and think “Bugs Bunny Reuben,” or admire the colorful stuffed avocado and its myriad creamy-crunchy textures, or the Mediterranean savor of an everything-spiced golden beet with glack garlic tahini, it’s obvious why co-owners Rich Landau and Kate Jacoby are perennial James Beard finalists. They’ve created a new culinary language with universal appeal.

There are so many indispensable classics, in fact, I sometimes wish they made more room for new ideas than the frequently changing but small “dirt list,” where I devoured tender pea leaves over dashi rice with matcha sauce and charred “elote” corn ringed by smoky mashed potatoes. They perhaps take more risks with the street food menu at their more casual V-Street off Rittenhouse Square. But the spirit of constant evolution is ever-present in Jacoby’s brilliant desserts, which deliver impossibly creamy (non-dairy) seasonal inspirations, from gorgeous fruit “cheesecakes” to a rich chocolate namelaka that came with purple Filipino ube ice cream one week, a Mexican inspiration with sweet corn ice cream the next. That’s a sweet bridge to gastronomic discovery I’ll hungrily cross any day.
Four-bell review: Vedge.
