The airy gnocchi made from Swiss chard, which harbor a deeper green savor than Vetri’s original spinach classic, practically melt beneath a gloss of brown butter while hand-folded tortellini stuffed with almond risotto beside them lavish in an ivory puddle of truffle cream. These two gems of pasta luxury are served on a divided plate as enduring signatures of Vetri’s two-decade legacy — inevitably eye-opening for first-timers, essential touchstones for longtime regulars.

But they were just the first in a wave of stunning pastas that reminded why chef Marc Vetri’s original Spruce Street townhouse remains the O.G. heartbeat of Philly’s noodle revolution. Tiny agnolotti pillows came stuffed with creamy summer corn. Hand-twisted ribbon straws of busiati tangled with braised pork and a sneaky chile heat. Zipper-edged pappardelle, flecked with the bran of house-milled Pennsylvania Redeemer wheat, wrapped around tender morsels of guinea hen and sweet peaches in natural juices that were transparent and illuminating at the same time. Impossibly fine but snappy fettuccine coiled into a long tube beneath tiny mushroom caps braised in prosecco.

There’s so much more, of course, to the full experience of a dream meal in this elegant 30-seat dining room, which has the rare Italian wines, Murano chandeliers and incredibly gracious hospitality to play its fine-dining role as the city’s most extravagant date: $500-$600 for two drinking light. Executive chef Matt Buehler’s customized tastings for each table assure no one goes hungry.

But the ethereal pastas are its undisputed life force. And as Vetri prepares for his next project in the coming months, a casual pasta bar in the Italian Market inspired by sold-out pop-ups in the Cucina’s private upstairs room, one hears an unmistakable excitement in his voice as the spotlight narrows on a more affordable, energetic showcase for his life’s work: “We’re not here resting on our laurels, and I’m saying, ‘How do we take the noodle to the next level?’”
If that means a more accessible stage for the Philly maestro’s pasta art, I can hardly wait.
Four-bell review: Vetri Cucina.

The airy gnocchi made from Swiss chard, which harbor a deeper green savor than Vetri’s original spinach classic, practically melt beneath a gloss of brown butter while hand-folded tortellini stuffed with almond risotto beside them lavish in an ivory puddle of truffle cream. These two luxury pasta gems are served on a divided plate as enduring signatures of Vetri’s two decade legacy — inevitably eye-opening for first-timers, essential touchstones for longtime regulars. But they were just the first in a wave of stunning pastas that reminded why chef Marc Vetri’s original Spruce Street townhouse remains the O.G. heartbeat of Philly’s noodle revolution.

Tiny agnolotti pillows came stuffed with creamy summer corn. Hand-twisted ribbon straws of busiati tangled with braised pork and a sneaky chile heat. Zipper-edged pappardelle, flecked with the bran of house-milled Pennsylvania Redeemer wheat, wrapped around tender morsels of guinea hen and sweet peaches in reduced natural juices that were transparent and illuminating at the same time. Impossibly fine but snappy fettuccine coiled into a long tube beneath tiny mushroom caps braised in prosecco.

There’s so much more, of course, to the full experience of a dream meal in this elegant 30-seat dining room, which has the rare Italian wines, Murano chandeliers and incredibly gracious hospitality to play its fine-dining role as the city’s most extravagant date: $500-$600 for two drinking light. Executive chef Matt Buehler’s customized tastings for each table assure no one goes hungry, from the “stuzzichini” nibbles of pastrami-smoked foie gras and house-cured coppa to the truffled onion crepe, primal goat over house-ground polenta and new dishes like braised rabbit with candied fennel and grass-fed Pennsylvania steak with blueberry agrodolce sourced from Vetri’s new investment in Primal Supply Meats.

But the ethereal pastas are its undisputed life force. And as Vetri prepares for his next project in the coming months, a casual pasta bar in the Italian Market inspired by sold-out pop-ups in the Cucina’s private upstairs room, one hears an unmistakable excitement in his voice as the spotlight narrows on a more affordable, energetic showcase for his life’s work: “We’re not here resting on our laurels, and I’m saying, ‘How do we take the noodle to the next level?’”
If that means a more accessible stage for the Philly maestro’s pasta art, I can hardly wait.
Read previous coverage: Vetri Cucina.

My early morning instincts typically lean savory, toward the Dutch-influenced items on Joncarl Lachman’s menu, like the frittata with braised rabbit, or the $7 Continental deaI with coffee, fresh jam, and thick slices of soft house-made milk bread perfumed recently with caraway. (Side of scrapple gravy is extra but recommended.) But Winkel is best in breakfast-splurge mode, and the deep-fried French toast is an indulgence that fits the bill. Its thick slices get soaked to bread-pudding moistness in an almond-scented ancient Dutch custard called “vla,” crisped in the fryer, then showered with sweet seasonal fruit, powdered sugar, and fresh whipped cream. By mid-fall, the sweet strawberries of late summer had disappeared in favor of cranberries and pears.

The Philly food world went wild with pride in May when the James Beard Foundation named Zahav as America’s Most Outstanding Restaurant in 2019.That was followed, instantly, by a communal onset of reservation dread. Now that we officially had to share this modern Israeli gem in Society Hill with the rest of the world, would we ever get in again? Absolutely — if you’re determined. But the fact is Zahav is now filled with far more out-of-towners than ever, from Sydney to Sacramento, who’ve planned trips to Philadelphia around their prized reservation.

For longtime fans, the continual evolution that’s been a Zahav hallmark is still present, especially as new chef de cuisine Chelsea Conrad (formerly at Butcher & Bee in Charleston) exerts a subtle Southern influence on dishes like tomatoes with fried okra and preserved lemon vinaigrette. But I’m genuinely thrilled for the newcomers, who get to experience Zahav’s classics for the first time. My shortlist of musts: You’ve had hummus, but not like Zahav’s Turkish variation, which get roasted in a steel crock with molten butter and Urfa peppers — an irresistible dip for the za’atar-dusted laffa flatbread, often baked by chef Michael Solomonov himself. (You can’t get the Turkish hummus at their more accessible hummusiya, Dizengoff.) Pan-fried haloumi is a salty, oozy cheese sensation wrapped in crispy brik paper, but a seasonal flourish of black plums drizzled with rosewater syrup made it ethereal. Don’t miss the fried cauliflower or the grilled duck hearts (if you’re adventurous).

But the limited lamb shoulder special remains the rock star of any Zahav dream. It anchors the off-menu “mesibah” feast, and I’ve yet to find a more intense — or more magnetic — lamb creation anywhere. It’s spice-cured, deeply smoked, confit in schmaltz then glossed in a dark pomegranate-lamb sweet-and-sour glaze. Plucked off the bone with tongs then savored over crispy Persian rice, each bite delivers a market bazaar’s worth of earthy, exotic flavors.

Save room for dessert. The malabi orchid custard scented with rose, or the chocolate-tehina mousse sandwiched in shredded kataifi  topped with fenugreek ice cream will leave a lasting impression. These unique, only-in-Philly flavors are absolutely still worth the effort of admission.
Four-bell review: Zahav.

The Philly food world went wild with pride last May when the James Beard Foundation named Zahav as America’s Most Outstanding Restaurant in 2019.That was followed, instantly, by a communal onset of reservation dread. Now that we officially had to share this modern Israeli gem in Society Hill with the rest of the world, would we ever get in again? Absolutely — if you’re determined. But the fact is Zahav is now filled with far more out-of-towners than ever, from Sydney to Sacramento, who’ve planned trips to Philadelphia around their prized reservation.

For longtime fans, the continual evolution that’s been a Zahav hallmark is still present, especially as new chef de cuisine Chelsea Conrad (formerly at Butcher & Bee in Charleston) exerts a subtle Southern influence on dishes like tomatoes with fried okra and preserved lemon vinaigrette. Chef Michael Solomonov continuously plays with staples like the raw lamb kibbe naya, shifting recently toward a more finely minced Palestinian style, with savory bursts of smoked lamb belly and hazelnuts.

But I’m genuinely thrilled for the newcomers. They get to experience Zahav’s classics for the first time, which are a parade of some of Philly’s most craveable flavors. My short list of musts: You’ve had hummus, but not like Zahav’s Turkish variation, which gets roasted in a steel crock with molten butter and Urfa peppers — an irresistible dip for the za’atar-dusted laffa flatbread, often baked by Solomonov himself. (The Turkish hummus isn’t available at their more accessible hummusiya, Dizengoff). Pan-fried haloumi is a salty, oozy cheese sensation wrapped in crispy brik paper, but a seasonal flourish of black plums drizzled with rosewater syrup made it ethereal. The fried cauliflower trend took off at Zahav, and for good reason. The grilled duck hearts? More a niche obsession, but one adventurous diners should indulge.

The limited lamb shoulder special, meanwhile, remains the rock star of any Zahav dream. It anchors the off-menu “mesibah” feast, and I’ve yet to find a more intense — or more magnetic — lamb creation anywhere than this massive joint of tender flesh. It’s spice-cured, deeply smoked, confit in schmaltz then glossed in a dark pomegranate-lamb sweet-and-sour glaze. Plucked off the bone with tongs then savored over crispy Persian rice, each bite delivers a market bazaar’s worth of earthy, exotic flavors.

Wash it down with a minty limonana punch or elegant red wine from the Bekaa or Galil Valleys. Then save room for dessert. The malabi orchid custard scented with rose, or the chocolate-tehina mousse sandwiched in shredded kataifi topped with fenugreek ice cream should leave a proper lasting impression. These unique, only-in-Philly flavors are absolutely still worth the effort of admission.
Read previous coverage: Zahav.

There are few small patches of Philly real estate I cherish more than the end-counter nook that marks the head of the line at the original Di Bruno Bros. in the Italian Market. It’s a tiny store — just 400-square-feet — but I can feel all 80-years-worth of merchant magic flowing to that spot as I scan the shelves packed with hundreds of the world’s greatest cheeses, geek out with the knowledgeable mongers, then taste the highlights before plunking down some serious cheese coin. Just recently, there was Ottanta al Tartufo, a truffled riff on Landaff from Jasper Hill made in honor of Di Bruno’s 80th birthday, a stunningly rich French Cremeaux de Citeaux tanged with crème fraîche, the smoky washed-rind Campo from North Carolina, and a line-up of grating cheeses — Locatelli, Fulvi Pecorino and Parmigiano-Reggiano — worthy of an Italian legend.

The Rittenhouse location (1730 Chestnut St.) doesn’t have quite the same Old Philly charm, even if it’s far larger. But I’m excited to see how, Alimentari, its airy new second-floor wine-and-cheese bar restaurant, continues to evolve. An early taste of milky burrata from its mozzarella bar, paired with tomato jam, saba, and satiny fresh slices of pink prosciutto, made a promising lunch, indeed. Cheeseboard options abound!

I’m in awe of the delicacy and grandmotherly touch that chef Ela Balka brings to her very traditional pierogies at Dinner House in Port Richmond. She doubles down on the earthy appeal of mushroom pierogi by floating them in a memorable bowl of ruby red borscht.
Read previous coverage: Dinner House Polish Cuisine.

It’s pricier than a typical food-court sushi kiosk, but this ambitious counter on Penn’s campus also serves the step up in fish quality expected from the quick-serve sibling of three-bell Double Knot (another upscale sushi favorite). The à la carte craftsmanship for take-out isn’t always consistent. This rating applies specifically to the hour-long omakase meals served by chef Yun Fuentes, which are a tremendous value at $35 for a multicourse tasting that is a study in creative twists with familiar fish — from a pristine fan of colorful mixed sashimi to a tuna-guacamole rice cracker and miso foie gras hand roll. Committing to the tasting is also a fine way to a secure counter seat in the chaotic Franklin’s Table food court.
Two-bell review: DK Sushi’s omakase.

There may be more onions than anything else on the onion-mopped kaiser steak, the signature indulgence at this classic Camden tavern (est. 1943), but it all comes together like French onion soup on a poppy-seeded bun — the saucy onions, the molten cheese, and yes, plenty of beef stacked high. House-fermented hot sauces are a plus, as is Donkey’s embrace of Jersey craft brewers like Tonewood, brewed just minutes away in Oaklyn.

It’s hard to say which came first, the idea to rehabilitate celery or the vintage celery plate. But this dish is another compelling victory for Adam Diltz’s back-to-PA-roots culinary campaign. The chef conjures up the vegetable’s sexy Victorian days by braising whole heads in pork stock, roasting them with Hootenanny goat Gouda, then serving them in dark jus, with a steak knife. Celery’s been waiting 100 years for this kind of comeback.

Most everything you need to know about Elwood is clear the moment the meal begins, when a rack of antlers comes to your table, its prongs bearing crispy brown cubes of venison scrapple dabbed with spruce jam. It doesn’t get more comfortable for the squeamish at this iconoclastic new BYOB once the frog legs dusted in cattail pollen show up over a pretty mini-pond of green garlic jus, alongside tureens of fresh snapping turtle soup, whole rabbits, and heritage-pig parts that roll by on silver platters, with minty scoops of sassafras sorbet to cleanse the palate.

But Elwood is not really about the shock value. For chef Adam Diltz, who converted this Fishtown rowhouse with his wife and partner, architect Jenny Ko, this project is also about paying homage to his rustic family roots in Northeast Pennsylvania and kindling a new passion for our disappearing foodways, an angle far too few local chefs are exploring at this level.

From a modern riff on historic catfish and waffles to plum-stuffed spelt dumplings, pot pies with house-smoked ham and country noodles, and whole roasted poultry from some of the region’s best farmers served in family-stye sharing feasts, dinner here is as meaningful as it is delicious.
Read previous coverage: Elwood. .

The region’s best corned beef is at the Famous, or anywhere, really, that owner Russ Cowan happens to be. The Brooklyn-born deli master has operated several delis in the area, but the 96-year-old Famous, which he bought from the Auspitz family in 2005, has become his ultimate homage to classic deli tradition. There are the impossibly huge piles of fragrant corned beef he cures and steams in-house. Fluffy matzo balls in schmaltz-dappled chicken broth ringed by vegetables and kreplach. Sweet and sour stuffed cabbage. Garlicky Roumanian skirt steak sliced into caramelized onions and mushrooms on a platter big enough for two.

With its vintage white tile and timeless window view onto Queen Village, the Famous also exudes that deli-as-institution vibe: a one-of-a-kind corner of Philly history (and politico power lunch hub) that demands a unique appreciation for the old ways that Cowan happens to possess. Yes, the

portions are too enormous and pricey. But when it’s time for a well-aged salami or the city’s finest smoked fish sliced by hand, there’s nowhere I’d rather go. Previous coverage: Famous 4th Street Delicatessen.

The Caesar as you know it arrives in a retro wooden bowl. But somehow, Joey Baldino has elevated the classic to its highest form in South Philly with the heady punch of anchovies and garlic for his zingy fresh dressing, croutons from house semolina bread, and so much grated cheese over top that it looks like Parmesan snow.

It was a members-only secret for nearly a century, until suddenly everyone wanted to belong to the Palizzi Social Club. The reason? Joey Baldino, who owns Zeppoli, transformed the rowhouse hideaway once owned by his uncle into a tribute to the family recipes he grew up with in the Italian Market, with definitive spaghetti in crab gravy, meltingly tender braciole, and spumoni made in-house. Paired with creative Italian cocktails and late hours that draw an industry crowd, it feels like a time capsule come to life.

Nonmembers need to find an in-the-know host to take them as guests if they want to know what stromboli, fresh sausage, or even a simple Caesar salad can be. A recent meatball special stuffed with buffalo mozzarella? Wow. And Baldino’s hand-shaved water ice, flavored with seasonally steeped syrups (apricot and almond one night), redefine the classic. Its private club status explains why I've assigned no official rating. But Palizzi is nonetheless one of Philly's most essential places to eat.
Read previous coverage: Palizzi Social Club.

Chef Ed Crochet also plays with live fire-roasted meats and exquisite fresh pastas at Fiore, the laid-back all-day cafe in Queen Village he owns with wife and pastry chef Justine MacNeil. The braided loops of Sardinian lorighittas with swordfish were a fascinating example of an obscure regional treasure inspired by their travels. But the beet mezzalune — plump half-moons stuffed with crimson beet ricotta that came dusted in poppy seeds and brown butter — were among the most beautiful things I’ve eaten this year.
Three-bell review: Fiore.

Georgians love cheese and bread so much, they have an entire genre dedicated to combination called khachapuri. The Megrelian-style dish looks like a sauceless pizza, its thick layer of molten sulguni — like a mozzarella but tangy from being brined — makes the ultimate cheese bread. But few foods anywhere are more majestic than the Ajarian khachapuri, a boat-shaped oval whose center is filled with sulguni and then topped with a cracked egg. Our server added a pat of butter, then scrambled it all together, transforming it into a sublimely rich cheese stuffing that looked like an eye beaming with yellow sunshine.
Two-bell review: Georgian Bakery & Cafe.

The slow-to-cook beggar's purse dumplings known as khinkali look sort of like Shanghai soup dumplings, but supersized and bulked up for the Caucasus mountain folk. Their twisted tops form a tip so dense, many habitués simply use it as a sturdy knob to hold the bundles and discard them after they take a bite. But be careful to lean over! The peppery pork and veal stuffings release a gush of flavorful broth, which can be sopped up with a crusty loaf of fresh shoti bread if you miss. Check-out this tutorial video in expert khinkali-slurping, recorded at nearby competitor Georgian Bakery & Cafe (11749 Bustleton Ave.).

The Good King Tavern has mastered a cool Gallic groove as an intimate Bella Vista bistro, and a destination for natural wines with the second-floor opening of its Le Caveau “bar à vins.” Cheese lovers, though, come for the Sunday Raclette, the bistro’s Savoyard reply to Italian Sunday Gravy that brings the pungent Alpine cheese broiled to a molten ooze over a steel crock of garlicky, salt-roasted Yukon Gold potatoes. With spicy Dijon and peppery frisee salad to help cut through the richness, this snack board hits light meal status with a generous addition of salty cured jambon de Bayonne.

No one’s more done more for dandan awareness over the last decade than Han Chiang, who a decade ago turned Philadelphians on to the fiery appeal of Szechuan cooking dialed up to a “10” on his sliding heat scale. There’s plenty of variation between kitchens now that he’s hit double-digit locations, including several in New York. But Han’s mom still makes the best Lion’s Head meatballs at the original Exton location. And one thing that’s consistent: Han Dynasty remains my dandan champ, with table-tossed noodle bowls that glisten with a sauce that perfect balances of spice, nutty sesame-peanut paste, peppercorn punch and savory meat crumbles with a balanced, resonating tang. The University City branch serving Penn and Drexel’s large community of international students, consistently delivers bold flavors.
Two-bell review: Han Dynasty.

Hardena Waroeng Surabaya is open, though it may look from the curb as though nothing's cooking inside this tiny corner storefront. But when you crack the door to the Widjojo family's modest luncheonette, the enticing smells of Indonesia drift out on a breeze warmed with coconut, hot sambal chili, and dark soy. I’m especially partial to Hardena’s chicken satay, which comes beneath a creamy flow of peanut sauce piqued by garlic and the palm-sugared soy darkness of kecap manis. A mix-and-match nasi campur rice plate with options like coconut-curried beef rendang, garlicky collards, vegan mashed jackfruit stew, or fish curry is, at $10-$12 a dish, among the greatest value meals in Philadelphia.

My photo editor friend may go for the corned beef, but Philly’s best pastrami is the prize at the small counter of this busy Reading Terminal deli, where the recipe descends from an owner’s uncle who once worked at legendary Katz’s in New York. Self-preservation dictates the fat-laced pastrami is only an occasional treat, so I’ve also honed a deep affection for the roast turkey “Rachel” grilled with coleslaw and Swiss on rye from venerable Kaplan’s New Model Bakery in Northern Liberties.

Fishtown has an impressive new sushi oasis tucked behind a round wooden door on an alley at the back of Wm. Mulherin’s Sons, where Hiroki Fujiyama, longtime sushi captain at Morimoto, is making a name for himself with omakases that rank among Philly’s top blowout meals. It’s a commitment at $135. But the 20 “courses” are substantial, and the meal melds pristine wild Japanese fish and cooked luxury ingredients with seasonality and master craftsmanship.

Refined service, an excellent drink program, and a warm room wrapped in white oak, cypress, and teak make a visit here a complete experience. The menu changes frequently, but the amadai tilefish seared inside the rippling crunch of its own scales, and special raw cuts of tsumu-buri rainbow runner jack and nodoguro blackthroat sea perch, are the kinds of fish that sushi-philes plan road trips around.
Three-bell review: Hiroki.

Owner Joe Groh has a larger spot in Fishtown (1 W. Girard Ave.) But there’s a special savor to the house-cut rib-eye steaks expertly grilled (with deeply caramelized onions) in the front window of the Wissinoming original, which still feels like the 1949 soda shop Groh purchased from mentor Samuel Sherman. This is the one soft-roll steak I really look forward to — especially with the nostalgic sip of a genuine black-and-white shake.

Any steak at John’s Roast Pork (14 E. Snyder Ave., 3 bells): John’s is the rare treasure that does several specialties at the highest level possible. In fact, the Bucci family has long made both my favorite cheesesteak and my favorite roast pork, all wrapped up inside a crusty Carangi’s roll and an 89-year-old shack’s worth of genuine South Philly atty-tude. If there’s a better griddle captain in town than John Bucci Jr. — ribbon-chopping his loin just right, meticulously tucking in the cheese, gutting his seeded rolls so all that weighty beefy goodness can fit — I haven’t found them yet.

What to order? You can’t miss with the classic flow of American with onions. But I also love the sharp provolone and spinach for its South Philly swagger. Or the John Jr. original of bruschetta topping for freshness. Even the chicken steak — a pre-frozen abomination most everywhere else — is cooked here from fresh breast and, with an optional streak of red gravy from the meatball pot, makes the best “healthy choice” I know. One caveat: John’s closes by midday and is never open Sundays, which means you might have to feed to those out-of-town weekend guests somewhere else.
Read previous coverage: John’s Roast Pork (three bells).

Chef Chutatip “Nok” Suntaranon dazzles with the rainbow of colors and complex crunch of her spicy khao yum kamin rice salad. But her treatment of the humble cabbage is just as miraculous, transforming those frumpy leaves with a splash of fish sauce and palm sugar — then a quick stir-fried singe in a smoking-hot wok — into something so sweet that it’s essentially cabbage candy.

For a city with such incredible diversity, great Thai food has long been a weak spot. But that all changed this year in a flash of the indigo dumplings, budu-fueled rice salads and sublime house-blended curries coming from Kalaya, the jam-packed BYOB that has brought the high-voltage Southern Thai flavors to the Italian Market.

Thai-born chef Chutatip “Nok” Suntaranon, who’s partnered with front-house gem My-Le Vuong, avoids the familiar options of pad Thai and chicken satay in favor of more boldly spiced dishes inspired by her family’s Nyonya-style Peranakan cuisine, which weaves ethnic Chinese and Malay threads into a distinctive regional repertoire. And refreshingly, she never taps the brakes for the perceived limitations of Western palates.

A ceviche-style dish called goong chae nam pla brings huge shrimp in a fiercely sour nam jim of fish sauce and lime tangled with fistfuls of cilantro and lip-stinging crushed chilies that heighten the buttery sweetness of the raw crustacean. The sultry chicken curry takes hours to make, simmering fresh-ground chile paste (peppers, lemongrass, turmeric, and lots of white peppercorn) into coconut cream with shrimp paste and chicken. Served alongside coconut rice greened with pandan leaves, the flavors bloom into waves of aromatics and lingering roasty spice. Crab meat curry over rice noodles, a ground beef curry dusky with red chilies and green peppercorns, and cuminy lamb penang all make their case for that next curry obsession. Meanwhile, don’t miss the warm ground duck laab that crunches with nuggets of crispy skin, roasted rice powder, and red chilies that Suntaranon patiently toasts until “they start to make me sneeze.”
I’d normally say Thai food in Philly is nothing to sneeze at. But Kalaya is the clear exception.
Read previous coverage: Kalaya.

We’ve had an opa-worthy boom in genuine gyro sandwiches made from whole chunks of meat (as opposed to the prefab industrial cones of ground meat). Nowhere does it better than this fragrant Cypriot grill, where pork and beef are layered with lots of marjoram and secret sauce (including onion juice and a soupcon of “mackerel essence”), then roasted on the vertical spit and rolled into a soft pita with a fistful of fries and yogurt tzatziki.

Los Tres Golpes is the ultimate Dominican power-up, and this downtown Camden standby serves it as the “Caribbean Breakfast.” The classic dish translates to “the three hits,” but there’s really four stars on this platter: fried rounds of salami, a bubbly crisp white cheese bar of queso frito, eggs, and fabulous mashed green plantains called mangú topped with vinegared onions that cut right through all that savor with a tangy spark. At just $6.99, it’s also a stellar deal.

Bread wiz Alex Bois somehow managed to top his High Street debut with his own next-level bakery where, behind glass walls at Craft Hall, his massive Czech deck oven turns out incredible seed-encrusted loaves, beet-infused pumpernickels, and soft-but-sturdy milk bread buns for restaurants, markets, and farm stands. My current obsessions are the ingeniously salty-sweet and “pretzelly AF” pretzel shortbreads as well as the “Homadama,” an intensely corny variation on crusty anadama made with hominy porridge. Lost Bread may set the region’s gold crust standard, but it’s leading a wave of talented new bakers. Other next-gen bread stars to look for include the Mighty Bread Co. (1211 Gerritt St., 215-607-3205), Philly Bread Co. (4530 Germantown Ave., 215-839-8694) and The Kettle Black (631 N. 2nd St.).

Don’t mistake this impressive independent for the similarly named national chain. Twins Davide and Gianni Primavera’s elegant destination is one of the gems of the Northeast, having evolved over a quarter-century from a small BYOB into a handsome full-service Italian with more than 100 indoor seats and a spectacular back patio lounge (P2) enclosed in glass that rivals any Center City space. The soulful and bountiful Sunday gravy, laden with house-made sausage and meatballs, is one of the best reasons to make the trip.

My current favorite Szechuan fix recently landed with a pepper-fired boom in an otherwise bland Exton strip mall thanks to a pharma tycoon who built this restaurant to remind his Chinese employees of home. The result, with a former Han Dynasty chef manning the woks, is one of the best examples of regional Chinese cooking in the area, including deftly balanced takes on dry-fried wings, complexly layered chile oil, deeply smoked duck, intensely cuminy lamb chops, and custardy cubes of mapo tofu cloaked in a fragrant haze of fresh ground peppercorns. The chile-boiled flounder is far more accessible to eat than its fire-engine-red gravy might suggest. But Mama Wong’s range goes well beyond heat. The sweet-and-sour spare ribs are irresistible, and this kitchen also happens to make some of the best Shanghai soup dumplings in the region.
Two-bell review: Mama Wong.

Philly has several good falafel options, from the coriander-crusted Egyptian fritters at Aya's Cafe (2129 Arch St.) in Logan Square to the nouveau falafel balls (with tahini shakes!) at Goldie (1526 Sansom St., 3401 Walnut St.). But I’ve quickly come to appreciate Philly’s first branch of legendary New York pioneer Mamoun’s (est. Greenwich Village 1971), which hits a sweet spot of affordability, chain consistency, and authentic Syrian flavors, with crisp balls that have vivid green centers fried to a craggy brown crunch that stands up to the mountain of pickles, veggies, and rivers of tahini that get tucked into the overstuffed pita. The lamb shawarma is also good, just beware the house hot sauce, which can burn your lips off.

Herb-scented manakeesh flatbreads are the signature savory at this casual Lebanese cafe in the heart of West Philly’s Muslim community. I like them with sujuk sausage or spiced ground meat bajeen. But the ultimate reason I make the trip is for the stunning array of house-baked baklava, which come in multiple syrup-soaked shapes alongside a display of sweet basboosas, mamoul shortbreads, and shamiyyat cookies stuffed with dates that reaffirm Lebanon’s pastry tradition as one of the world’s greatest.

If you’ve only eaten a Schmitter at one of the stadiums, you don’t know how good it can be. Head to this 98-year-old original tavern in Chestnut Hill where the fourth-generation McNallys use better ingredients to carry on the classic version of their cheesesteak variation —  tanged with fried salami, grilled tomato, and signature sauce on a kaiser roll — conceived in 1964 for a regular who liked his Schmidt’s beer.

House-made short rib corned beef is a cornerstone of Matt Cahn’s vision for updating the deli and diner counter tradition with a fresh touch at this 18-seat luncheonette near Jefferson Hospital. And his take on the Reuben is good. But when that corned beef is piled over fluffy eggs and seeded rye for the “Herschel Walker,” you have breakfast sandwich greatness to start your day in mensch mode. Two-bell review: Middle Child.

We come to my family’s favorite low-key taqueria for the stunningly complex signature mole and tamales. But on weekends, the Ríos family also makes one of the city’s best barbacoas de chivo — sublimely earthy, addictively gamey goat — which, like its more famous counterpart just up the street at South Philly Barbacoa, comes with a side of deeply flavorful consommé steeped from the drippings.
Three-bell review: Mole Poblano.

Poblano-style mole is the mother sauce of the Mexican community that came largely from the state of Puebla to settle in South Philly. And this complex, time-consuming blend of cinnamon-tinged chocolate, sesame, nuts, multiple chilies, various fruits, and animal crackers is the rightful specialty at Mole Poblano, where its sweet dark and spicy mystery graces everything from morning eggs to tamales and enchiladas. No option satisfies, though, quite like the signature presentation of bone-in chicken that’s stewed to tenderness and whose own natural juices add yet another layer of depth to the mole’s story.
Three-bell review: Mole Poblano.

Philly’s Polish tradition gets a youthful boost at this charming cafe connected to the roaming food cart, where Ryan Elmore and Kaitlin Wines get creative with both savory and sweet pierogi, including a blueberry-stuffed dessert special with brown butter and house-made sour cream ice cream.

On a bitter-cold winter day, nothing warms my bones quite like a bowl of scrippelle inside cozy Mr. Joe’s Cafe. This classic Abruzzese soup of Pecorino-stuffed crepe rolls bobbing in nourishing broth represents deep ancestral comfort for many local Italian-Americans, and few restaurants make it with as much of a homey touch as this throwback luncheonette at Greenwich and South Eighth Streets. It’s a passion project of family recipes steeped in Vince Termini Sr.’s big steam kettles in the back of the Termini family’s legendary bakery across the street. Dust that bowl with a snowfall of more Pecorino, proceed to the gnocchi crowned with a silk-tender roulade of flank steak braciola, and then hit one of those famous cannolis for the home run finish.

This tiny Pennsport BYOB is one of the most adventurous new kitchens in the city. Its greatest dish, though, is one of its simplest: hand-shaped pastas that chef-owner Ari Miller flavors with an ever-changing array of seasonings worked into the dough, from dusky silk chilies to cracked black pepper and Egyptian fennel, then tosses in minimalist lemon-butter sauce. Two-bell review: Musi.

I’m usually wary of upscaled steaks that overshoot the cheesesteak’s elemental appeal with the easy cheat of luxury toppings. But Ari Miller’s “Frizwit,” a pop-up favorite that predates his creative new BYOB, simply and effectively upgrades the classic with better ingredients: grass-fed local beef, a Philly Bread Co. roll with just the right chew and crust, a creamy white cheese sauce made from Philabundance cheddar and local beer, and caramelized onion ribbons. True to its origins, the Frizwit still appears only in pop-up status, drawing crowds to the picnic tables outside the restaurant the first Monday of every month, when the kitchen is normally closed.
Two-bell review: Musi.

Port Richmond gets a taste of the Mexican revival with this stylish corner cantina from three restaurant-scene vets, including two from Mexico, who meld authentic roots with warm service and a modern touch. Some of Philly’s most supple handmade tortillas make the well-crafted toppings shine, from my favorite new fish taco (mahi-mahi suspended in a crisp cloud of Modelo Negra batter tinged with Valentina hot sauce), a cauliflower taco I actually liked, and a memorably distinctive riff on al pastor: glazed pork belly for the CDMX.
Read more coverage: Nemi.

Earthy with whole grains, charred and smoky from the grill that crisps the craggy edges of its hand-ripped chunks, the rustic Nordic loaves made daily by Jonathan Yacashin instantly set the tone and identity for this Dutch-themed BYOB, where you’ll inevitably buy the menu item called “Another serving of Jonathan’s bread” because the house-whipped, flavored butter of the day is awesome, too.

One could write an epic tome about Italian stuffed pastas alone. But gnudi are special because they’re dough-free dumplings whose ricotta cheese stuffing miraculously forms its own delicate skin during the cooking process. Chris D’Ambro uses these melt-away lovelies as a seasonal showcase for everything from favas with mint and lemon butter in spring to sweet corn and charred cherry tomatoes by summer’s end.

Everyone talks about the “Dinosaur Egg” —  a poached egg wrapped inside an avocado that gets wrapped in bacon then deep-fried. But I was swayed by the well-put-together breakfast burrito special at this stylish black-and-white Fishtown bruncherie, then couldn’t stay away from the monkey bread, a warmed-to-order pull-apart loaf that comes with a spoon to bathe it in hot salted caramel.

A recommendation for oysters might sound obvious, given the name. But nothing is given in a town once ruled by grand fish houses that is now essentially down to its last standard-bearer. But the Oyster House does more than merely survive. It’s managed to both embrace history and reinvent itself as an essential cornerstone of our dining scene as the region’s prize pearl of oyster craft. Get those mollusks fried in fine cornmeal flour beside a scoop of cool chicken salad for the most craveable of old-school Philly lunches. Order them delicately roasted three ways (the BBQ style even comes smouldering). This restaurant’s raw bar powers, though, are unsurpassed, both in the skill of its veteran shuckers and its mission to champion — and foster —  the budding resurgence of local oysters. You’ll want to taste of the freshest Cape May Salts, Rose Coves, Sweet Amalias, and Sugar Shack Cocktails from the Jersey coast, and there is no better place to go.

Other raw-bar stars: Royal Boucherie (52 S. 2nd St., 267-606-6313, three bells); Friday Saturday Sunday (261 S. 21st St., 215-546-4232, three bells); Parc (227 S. 18th St., 215-545-2262, three bells), Pearl’s Oyster Bar (Reading Terminal Market, 51 N. 12th St., 215-964-9792); a.bar (1737 Walnut St., 215-825-7035).

Chef Matt Gentile revels in making his own cheeses. He stains his ricotta purple with Chianti to garnish wild boar rigatoni. But his most impressive cheesecraft is a glistening white goat’s-milk burrata that he stretches from house-made curds, the resulting ball of fresh mozzarella delivering an extra tenderness and delicately funky tang that cow’s milk mozz cannot achieve. The sheer, rose-colored slices of coppa ham on the side were also made in-house and cured in the wine cellar downstairs.

Northeast Philly’s Brazilian-style churrasco trailblazer, long my preference over chains like Fogo de Chao, recently opened a Center City branch in the former Garces Trading Co. The ambiance is a little awkward, but the quality of roasted meats brought to the table by roving servers is superior to the chain alternative, especially the signature picanha top sirloin. Considering the massive amount of all-you-can-eat salt-crusted red meat to be consumed, though, I still prefer a trip to the low-key Northeast original, which benefits from real charcoal fires not permitted in Center City.

The superlatives can hardly be grander for Joe Beddia’s pizza magic. A famous food mag launched the national stampede by calling his pies the “Best Pizza in America” when he ran a tiny take-out corner where he made so few each night that hardly anyone could taste them. Now that he’s managed the improbable and translated that quirky artisan vision into a pizza palace for the masses, Time declared Beddia 2.0 one of the 100 greatest places in the world — up there with a wild elephant park in Africa and Disneyland’s Star Wars theme park.

Well, just finding the tiny Fishtown side street where Beddia’s new sprawling digs reside behind an unmarked steel gate is an adventure. And this is one place that lives up to the hype. The airy industrial space with al fresco seating and communal tables is undeniably cheerful. The bar is one of the city’s prime showcases for natural wines. There are fabulous salads with inventive tweaks (roasted veggies for the Caesar; fish sauce for the vinaigrette) and coffee soft-serve ice cream drizzled with amaro that delivers a vividly caffeinated dairy buzz.

Most important, the pizzas deliver crispy-edged American pies with original seasonal touches that resonate for hours after they’ve been devoured. The chile-spotted “angry” arrabiata pie is one of the great spicy foods in the city. The #4 will make an anchovy aficionado out of any skeptic. There are pizzas with cream-dappled seasonal greens. Zesty red rounds with housemade sausage. Even the Philly-style tomato pie — focaccia-like squares with oil-crisped bottoms, spongy centers and layers of heat-caramelized tomato sauce — sets a new standard.
Three-bell review: Pizzeria Beddia.

The whole notion of a “hoagie omakase” is simultaneously the most preposterous and Philly thing ever. Who would ever pay $500 to sit with a handful of friends in a private room and eat hoagies, that crusty emblem of our blue-collar soul? Turns out, a lot of people, once they learned that pizza genius Joe Beddia hatched this plan for a hidden alcove at the back of his popular pizzeria. And the fee pays for much more than just six hoagies — most of the menu, in fact, including several stellar pies, dessert, and a round of drinks.

It also turns out, these aren’t just normal hoagies, either. They’re built on exceptional house-baked rolls by hoagie master John Walker (“Hoagie Wan Kenobi,” jokes Beddia), who meticulously layers in three different kinds of stuffings. Tucked between the delicate crunch of both top and bottom crusts, each resonates with extra vivid volume.

Bitter broccoli rabe, sweet peppers, and deeply caramelized mushrooms with lemon aioli. Oily tuna amped up with a back beat of smoked sardines, moistened by sweet golden tomatoes, piquant tapenade, and a creamy ribbon of Boursin cheese. Walker’s classic Italian, meanwhile, looks remarkably familiar. But every detail is so perfectly tuned: the sheer pink sheets of spicy capicola and sweet mortadella peeled straight off the slicer, summer ripe tomatoes, a cushion of shaved iceberg adding spring beneath the young provolone. It’s not so much a “fancy” hoagie as the classic reimagined as its best self. An aspirational hoagie. And we devour it hungrily, hoping to glimpse a piece of our best selves, too, in that splendid feast.

Joe Beddia lands his own creative riff on the Caesar with oven-roasted vegetables at the core in lieu of romaine. But it’s his use of fish sauce vinaigrette for a salad of apples, radishes, lettuces, and almonds that will be his lasting contribution to Philly’s salad canon.

A famous food mag launched the national stampede by calling his pies the “Best Pizza in America” when he ran a tiny take-out corner where he made so few each night that hardly anyone could taste them. Now that he’s managed the improbable and translated that quirky artisan vision into a pizza palace for the masses, Time declared Beddia 2.0 one of the 100 greatest places in the world — up there with a wild elephant park in Africa and Disneyland’s Star Wars theme park.

Well, just finding the tiny Fishtown side street where Beddia’s new sprawling digs reside behind an unmarked steel gate is an adventure. And this is one place that lives up to the hype. The airy industrial space with al fresco seating and communal tables is undeniably cheerful. The bar is one of the city’s prime showcases for natural wines. There are fabulous salads with inventive tweaks ( roasted veggies for the Caesar; fish sauce for the vinaigrette) and coffee soft-serve ice cream drizzled with amaro that delivers a vividly caffeinated dairy buzz.

Most important, the pizzas deliver crispy-edged American pies with original seasonal touches that resonate for hours after they’ve been devoured. The chile-spotted “angry” arrabiata pie is one of the great spicy foods in the city. The No. 4 will make an anchovy aficionado out of any skeptic. There are pizzas with cream-dappled seasonal greens. Zesty red rounds with housemade sausage. Even the Philly-style tomato pie — focaccia-like squares with oil-crisped bottoms, spongy centers and layers of heat-caramelized tomato sauce — sets a new standard. And then there is Beddia’s latest wacky creation: a special-reservation for a hoagie omakase feast. Can Philly’s best pizzeria redefine the classic Philly sandwich, too? Beddia and his hoagie master, John Walker, just might.
Read previous coverage: Pizzeria Beddia.

It’s all about the seasonal fish and special red vinegar rice at this Queen Village sushi counter, which specializes in slightly more accessible versions of typically luxe omakase tastings, including a $58 option that delivers 12 well-crafted bites within a brisk 60-minute period. You’ll have to spend nearly double, though, if you actually aim to fill up on fish, and both the service and space at this BYOB are minimalist.

Chef-owner Xiang Yu “Sam” Lin has brought his best recipes and some special fish-aging techniques from a 10-year tour of Manhattan sushi hot spots, with oysters in yuzu foam, scallops dusted with charcoal salt, and a Peking duck foie gras taco for a cooked kaiseki mid-course. Lin also specializes in some counterside smack talk for his local omakase competition. But he delivers enough cuts of coveted fish, from kohada gizzard shad to sayori needle fish, sea eel, aged hamachi, and kinmedai with white kelp to back up his status as one of Philly’s new sushi players to watch.
Three-bell review: Sakana.

Chef Lou Boquila’s second showcase for updated Filipino cuisine, a follow-up to Perla off East Passyunk, brings some edgier bagoong-powered flavors to a sleek Fishtown BYOB, from the magic crunch of puffed beef tendon chicharrons to ukoy shrimp wrapped in a nest of fried sweet potato strings, chicken adobo and the colorful, refreshing halo-halo for dessert.
Two-bell review: Sarvida.

Come for the “saw-zidge ’n’ figs,” stay for a taste of old-school South Philly Italian flavors at this friendly corner BYOB. Regulars go for the garlicky steamed artichokes whose leaves are cushioned with seasoned bread crumbs and creamy Pecorino sauce. But don’t miss the standout clams Casino, piled-high seafood pastas, and “Italiano” chops as co-owner and chef Christian Varalli pays homage to his dad’s longtime Atlantic City institution. Over its 16 years on South Broad Street, Scannicchio’s has remained one of the best of a dying breed of legacy Italian-American kitchens while also embracing its place in the neighborhood’s increasingly diverse landscape of newer immigrant flavors. It’s a great stop near the stadiums to pregame on fresh calamari and scungilli fra diavolo — if you’re lucky enough to get a table.
Two-bell review: Scannicchio’s.

Korean flavors have now firmly landed in Center City’s mainstream consciousness with a wave of bright new restaurants, including a downtown branch of Seorabol. But none delivers quite the edge of spice, fermented funk, and char-kissed savor that galbi fans find at the original in Olney, a mainstay of North Philly’s fading Koreatown that’s one of the last BBQ houses to still use real charcoal in its tabletop grills.

The galbi short ribs, expertly butterflied by two generations of Cho men so the meat unspools in long ribbons of marbled beef, quickly singe atop the flames. The lightly scored meats, already marinated in sesame oil, sake, scallions, and pureed Asian pear,  absorb the charcoal smoke as an extra nuance that caramelizes over the crackling heat. Each hot snip of intense meatiness is then dabbed with sweet ssamjang paste and rolled into the cool crunch of a lettuce bundle with warm rice, raw garlic chips, and slivered moons of hot chiles.

We come for the full spectrum of lamb-centric Uzbek flavors at Daniel Yukhananov’s homage to his upbringing as a Bukharian Jew from Tashkent, from cumin-flecked lamb plov to meat-stuffed manti and samsa pastries. But the restaurant’s called Shish-Kabob Palace for a reason: a mixed grill of flavorful skewers laced with marinated chicken, “lulya” ground lamb, and skirt steak is only topped by the lamb chops that get flambéed tableside.

They don’t call Sid Booker Sr. the “Colonel of Shrimp” for nothing. The pink takeout window at Belfield and Broad has been a late-night destination for his deep-fried jumbo shrimp since 1962. Booker still comes in daily to sprinkle his magic dust over greaseless crustaceans that are so sweet, plump, and delicately crunchy, I understand why the post-club crowds keep this North Philly corner rocking until 4 a.m. on weekends.

I’m thrilled the family behind the now-closed Khmer Kitchen is back in business at this snug bi-level corner with an upstairs dining room on Washington Avenue. Because the Cambodian flavors emerging from its kitchen are among the most electric I’ve tasted this year, from the irresistibly funky-spicy ground pork dip with crudité veggies (prahok kteah) to stuffed chicken wings plumped with lemongrass sausage, hot and sour country soup (sgnao jrok mohn), bitter flower salad, and memorably tender fried frog legs with a peppery lime dip.

Putting vegetables in a starring role is one of the best qualities of Spice Finch, Jennifer Carroll and Billy Riddle’s homage to modern-Med flavors, where you can graze on farro-stuffed grape leaves with apricots, Berbere carrots, and a tagine of beans over puffed warm grains. But I’ve never had anything quite like their broccoli tabouleh. It features raw broccoli that’s been grated into couscous-sized grains that lend a distinctive crunchy chew to quinoa salad brightened with fistfuls of herbs, a bright squeeze of lemon and drizzle of Soom tahini.

Turkish manti stuffed with lamb come in many forms and many sizes, from the tiny foldovers bobbing in yogurt and chile butter at Isot Mediterranean Cuisine (622 S. 6th St.) to the softball-sized Uzbek ovals with braided pleats that take 45 minutes to steam at Shish Kabob Palace (1683 Grant Ave.). My manti of the moment, though, are the crowd-pleasers at Stina Pizzeria in South Philly, where fragrant ground lamb stuffing fills pyramid-shaped dumplings set between clouds of whipped yogurt that float atop orange streaks of Aleppo chile oil.

Philly’s long and unlikely love affair with grilled octopus is largely thanks to Dmitri Chimes, whose self-named BYOB Dmitri’s (795 S. 3rd St., 215-625-0556; 944 N. 2nd St., 215-592-4550) remains one of the city’s best bets for no-frills seafood with a Greek flair. Leave it to another Greek-American, Bobby Saritsoglou, for giving octopus a compelling modern update — and one of the Mediterranean highlights at his charming Stina Pizzeria near West Passyunk. It’s patiently simmered for hours with citrus, herbs, and fennel, then roasted to a crunchy-sucker crisp in the oven. That’s when the meaty arm lands like an artful “S” on the plate, dappled with flowers and curving between dramatic swipes of black garlic sauce, scoops of olive tapenade and smoky red romesco, and a whiff of citrus ash made from the dust of dehydrated lemons and oranges.

There’s been a breakfast bump in the suburbs, too, including this cheerful strip mall destination serving a menu of creatively upgraded favorites.  I was sooo grateful for “The Grateful Dad” upgrade to creamed chipped beef. The breakfast tacos hit the spot, too. But what was that levitating above my wife’s plate? The fluffiest, high-rise pancakes I’ve seen in a long time.

Late night taco-holics used to know this zero-frills Italian Market storefront as Prima Pizza, but it stopped making pizza, so the name was changed. What Prima still does make are some of the boldest, biggest tacos around, piled high with pickled nopales cactus strips, grilled green onions and a roasted jalapeño. I’m a fan of its vividly orange-spiced al pastor, but the tender lengua here (along with the Oaxacan-style tamales wrapped in banana leaves) are also a draw — as late as 1 a.m. weekdays and 4 a.m. some weekend nights.

I usually avoid lunch buffets. But Center City’s other big South Indian arrival this year has changed my mind with its quality and distinctive regional flavors. Thanal, a bi-level corner tavern in Logan Square, draws huge crowds from the nearby business district for a buffet laden with uttapam, goat curries, and bottomless Hyderabadi biryani. The nighttime scene benefits from the perk of a bar mixing creative turmeric- and cardamom-accented cocktails and an  à la carte menu that steps up to some more refined entrees (stewed lamb shanks, karahi curry, gunpowder shrimp), along with a broad menu of other hard-to-find Tamil-flavored classics, including goat trotter paya soup and tandoor-roasted pomfret.
Two-bell review: Thanal.

This pioneering cafe group showcasing artisan wines, beer, and cheese became even more engaging last year when renowned author Tenaya Darlington (a.k.a. Madame Fromage) became its Cheese Goddess. She has excelled at weaving locally produced gems (Cherry Grove, Lindendale, Goat Rodeo) alongside her penchant for esoteric international “funksters” like Formaggio di Fossa, a Pecorino that gets buried, then unearthed in fall. Tria’s “Sunday School” feature is the perfect way to explore new things at a 50% discount.

There’s much more than coffee at chef Greg Vernick’s posh breakfast hideaway, its blond wood mezzanine space hovering like a contemporary treehouse over the new Comcast Technology Center’s lobby trees. All of the baked goods are top-notch, from the matcha green tea-white chocolate croissant to the kouign-amann oozing strawberry-passion fruit caramel. But Vernick’s oatmeal soufflé was the revelation. It comes quivering and hot, hovering a solid inch above its ramekin with nutty beads of steel cut grain suspended in a citrusy sweet cloud. Add a dollop of maple-sweetened whipped cream, and you may agree: Breakfast in Philly these days is on the rise.
Three-bell review: Vernick Coffee Bar.

This cheerful Kensington sibling to Vientiane Cafe, Philly’s Lao pioneer in West Philly, is one of the best in a recent Lao boomlet. I need the crispy rice salad, garlicky house-made sausages, curried coconut khao poon “King Soup,” and green papaya salads that crunch with the cuisine’s signature blend of sour, spice, and twang. The location sits north of the River Wards’ more gentrified zones, but adds yet another bright destination (with good Thai specialties, too) to a stretch of storefronts below the El that already hosts two of the city’s best pho shops.
Two-bell review: Vientiane Bistro.
I’m not going to pretend this is my healthy veg, but if they make asparagus in heaven, I expect them to be crisply fried and glossed in the golden gloss of garlic scampi butter from Villa di Roma.

Can you smell the meatballs simmering? Basil DeLuca has been hand-making them all morning, just as he has nearly every day for the last 26 years. “That gravy is the heart of this restaurant,” says Basil’s brother, Epiphany “Pip” DeLuca, who, with his five siblings and their children, runs Villa di Roma as his father, Domenic, did beginning in 1963. There are fancier Italians in town and other red-gravy elders, like Ralph’s and Dante & Luigi’s, that have their virtues. But no restaurant magically touches South Philly’s Italian-American soul with as much familial warmth as Villa di Roma, where the unpretentious brick dining room remains a destination for ravioli with garlic bread and fried asparagus in scampi butter.

Beyond the essential all-beef meatballs, there’s a surprisingly deep repertoire handed down from the legendary chef Vince “Cuz” Pilla: zippy chicken Sicilian; sausage broiled Genovese-style with “’scarole” and beans; thick tuna steak in Sicilian tomato sauce sparked with olives and cherry pepper zing. There’s excellent flounder francaise, too, as well rich pastas like the “quattrocini” alfredo variation with prosciutto and spinach, or hearty Ziti Francis tossed with chicken and veal beneath molten mozzarella. Finesse cooking? Definitely not. But my regular desire for veal Parm layered with an extra eggplant cutlet — followed by a cannoli or fluffy tiramisu — is the definition of a power craving.
Three-bell review: Villa di Roma.

There’s an electric zing to the ceviche mix of flounder, shrimp, and calamari at this handsome ode to Peruvian flavors in Old City. Laced with crunchy red onions, the citrusy leche de tigre marinade was equal turns tart, spicy, and lit with ginger — a legacy of Japan's influence on Peru. The traditional garnishes of giant choclo corn kernels and sweet potato, meanwhile, lend the perfect counterpoints to bring all those bright flavors into balance.

Served as an entire bird on the bone that’s butterflied wide open, the Pakistani Chargha at this West Philly kabob shop is deeply scored then crisped inside a vivid orange crust that’s more spice rub than batter, with a penetrating marinade of yogurt and lime that reaches every cranny. I easily tug away the plumes of juicy meat and the flavors snap my eyes open with citrus that swirls into currents of ginger, cumin, and garam masala curry, with a lingering hum of heat. Pair it with a spicy ground chicken kabob and one of the restaurant’s fresh-baked dimpled flat breads.
Two-bell review: Wah-Gi-Wah.

I’d climb a Himalayan mountain to eat a dinner of momo dumplings. Thankfully, we just need to get up the hill to Roxborough where Philly’s first Tibetan restaurant recently opened. There are a lot of intriguing flavors here, which show both Chinese and Indian influences. But momos are a true Tibetan specialty, and White Yak serves a meal’s worth of these hearty, well-pleated dumplings stuffed with chicken, beef, or vegetables. Wash it down with a bowl of spiced beef broth and salted butter tea.

Speaking of Barclay Prime … Stephen Starr’s posh contemporary steakhouse off Rittenhouse Square remains, after 15 years, the city’s prime pilgrimage stop to spend lavishly on $30 Manhattans, gaudy Wagyu-foie gras cheesesteaks (no, thanks) and $195 imported A5 ribeyes. Nonetheless, this kitchen still has polish most steakhouses don’t, and Barclay’s second-tier cuts would pass for ultimate beef anywhere else. Exhibit A: the perfectly cooked 32-ounce prime porterhouse with an extraordinary dry-aged savor and more than enough meat for two or three to share, a worthy compromise splurge at $105. After a mid-life sag of inconsistency that saw its rating dip temporarily to two bells in 2012, Barclay Prime has bounced back nicely and regained its special-occasion glow, cruising once again at the three-bell purr you'd expect from one of Philly's luxury classics.

I don’t love the cheese-and-chive popovers here simply because they’re one of the few freebies at Philly’s most expensive steakhouse. When you crack open one of these hot pastry balloons and inhale the cheesy steam, and then devour a couple more, you’ll be fully primed for a night of indulgence.

Chinatown’s most venerable destination for reliable Szechuan cooking recently unveiled a cool modern makeover, the big space now divided by circle-pierced walls and private rooms for a stylish look. The cooking, though, remains classic and prodigious, with a vast menu that ranges from the house special frogs to diced rabbit with orange peels; crisply fried cubes of Chongqing chicken; mapo tossed in heartily meaty gravy; and a favorite appetizer of sliced beef and tripe in chile oil (fu qi fei pian) that comes laced with cilantro and the bonus sparks of crunchy fried mung beans.

Sometimes (no, all the time) I crave the simplest virtues of a classic corner diner: just like the friendly counter seats and creamy chipped beef toast at the tiny Fairlane Grill, which has perched at the end of a residential block in leafy Erdenheim for 21 years. The Western-style scrambled eggs and fluffy pancakes were made for a perfect lazy Saturday morning start — until I learned of the longtime owners’ plans to sell, faced with the desire to retire, and perhaps, the same economic forces (i.e. chains) that have doomed so many of our traditional diners. “What’s good here?” asked a man coming in just as I held the door to step out. “Everything,” I said. “Enjoy it while you can.”

There are several distinctive things to eat this fragrant corner restaurant in West Philadelphia, perhaps Philly’s only Yemenite kitchen. But the bubbling clay crock of shredded lamb stew called fahsah is alone worth the trip. Eat it with a bubble-crisped round of fresh flatbread and a special request side of hilbeh, a whipped fenugreek dip that dials up the earthy factor to 1,000. Follow with a  cup of cardamom-flavored Yemenite tea.

The only thing better than a good biscuit is the great biscuit enriched with beef fat at ITV, the gastropub connected to Laurel where it comes with honey-chive butter — an A-plus comfort foundation for some of Philly’s most innovative cocktails.

The eighth-floor views of the city are are so inspiring from this moody cocktail bar atop the Bok Building, you’ll want an excuse to linger. Chef Paul Garberson’s grand mezze is just the thing, a vast sharing platter that ranges from personal takes on classic Middle Easter dips (smoky baba, lemony hummus, tangy-swet walnut-pepper ezme salad) to airy carrot and feta fritters, deep-fried olives, and a colorful bouquet of pickles.

It used to be Philly’s fancy burgers were all about big bopper girth — an open-wide show-off phase that now seems in decline after the overcooked disappointments I recently encountered at old favorites Rouge and Village Whiskey. But the lusciousness of a plump patty done right is still alive and well — maybe better than ever — at Kensington Quarters, the pioneering whole-animal kitchen in Fishtown where a 75-25 blend of grass-fed local chuck from Happy Valley Meats is cut and ground on site daily.

The texture of that fresh coarse grind is key to this $20 half-pound handful. But the smoky details that take it to the next level, the crusty backyard-esque char of the wood-fired grill, smoked raw milk Lancaster cheddar, smoked garlic aioli, tart house pickles for bright crunch, then a mop of caramelized onions soaked in beef jus that accelerate the drip. The mega-flow, somehow, does not dissolve the sweet potato bun made by Philly Bread, whose pliant softness instead molds perfectly around this beefy abundance. Many of the same ingredients are used for the quick-serve KQ Burger stand at Franklin’s Table (3401 Walnut St.), but true to trend, it’s a double-patty edition built for speed.

Those who miss Salumeria from the Reading Terminal can find the elusive taste of its signature balsamic dressing once again at this new artisan deli in South Kensington, launched by former Salumeria employee Matt Budenstein. The must-order here, though, is the Della Casa, a zesty Italian with locally made “gabagool” from 1732 Meats wrapped around milky fresh mozzarella that’s stretched in-house daily.

My office is right around the corner from Chinatown, so I get regular cravings for the classic rice porridge known as congee. I frequent several tea and pastry stops for take-out. But if I have time to sit, I’ll savor the Hong Kong-style duck house add-ons at nearby M Kee, where bits of amber-skinned roast duck are a solid choice, but I also love the chopped beef, which blends seamlessly into the thick ivory puree of rice-thickened broth laced with shredded ginger and fresh scallions. For extra crunch, order fresh-fried crullers on the side for dipping.

The Western ’burbs remain the ultimate destination for a dosa trek, with longtime South Indian favorites like Bangles (889 E. Lancster Ave., Downingtown) and counter service-casual Indian Hut Curry & Cakes (260 N. Pottstown Pike, Exton) still going strong. But the pleasantly modern dining room behind the strip mall facade of Manam is a wonderful place to discover some softer dosa variations, like the bowl-shaped appam rounds and onion-laced rice batter pancakes of kal dosai, which are both ideal for sopping up richly spiced coconut milk curries. The mutton chukka, chicken 65 and tandoor-roasted specialties of Jinga prawns and Zaffroni malai chicken kebabs were also memorable.

Most people go to home improvement stores for building supplies and spring flowers. I go to inhale the smell of Maglio’s sausages roasting in coils on the flat-top griddles inside these surprising little grill hut havens that front several Home Depots. I get my Conshy Bakery roll stuffed with a mix of hot and sweet links, but am counting on an early morning lightbulb or battery run soon to sample the well-regarded breakfast sandwiches.

Vacherin Mont d’Or, the oozy, spruce-wrapped round that’s one of the world’s great stinky cheeses, is celebrated each November at this romantic French bistro with a three-course menu for four. The centerpiece is the cheese baked with wine in its own box as fondue, served with potatoes, sausage, salad, and wine pairings to celebrate the flavors of the Jura.
